As it stands, it's completely obvious from the start that the roaches will turn out to be innocent people.As another reviewer mentioned, history and the present day continue to show us that certain humans need no excuses to oppress others and visit violence upon other people who are different. The idea that a human would only kill another human if they resemble a literal monster is absurd to the point of farce - completely divorced from the reality of the world and human nature. A regime can always find violent thugs ready to get out there and guiltlessly follow orders.The eugenics angle seems a little silly. If they had the blood results for these undesirables, why would they be eliminating them in such a haphazard way? Why wouldn't they take care of them at the time of the testing? It's possible I misunderstood the nature of the testing, or that they only decided later on to exterminate these people, or that they somehow escaped. I guess the bloodwork results wouldn't be instant. This version of administering eugenics just comes off as goofy.It just seems odd to me that if the elites decided to exterminate these "inferior" people, that they would do it in such a bizarre way. The logic is that they want future generations to inherit good traits, but the world the "normal" villagers are living in looks crummy as hell anyway. It doesn't seem to me like they are caring about quality of life for the "normal" people, so why would they care so much if they got some bad genes? Wouldn't it make more sense for the well bred powerful people just to isolate themselves away from the undesirables?The ideas of fascism and eugenics are completely unoriginal- to the point that the villain comes off as a one dimensional moustache Twirler. For this episode to be compelling you need to be able to sympathise with the villain in some way.It really just feels like this world is unrealistic and the episode didn't do a great job of explaining the logic of the world.

Title: The weakest episode so far
Comment: I am following the series in chronological order and so far, I found something interesting in each episode. Unfortunately, this story is just a banal politically correct statement.It is based on the unrealistic premises that human beings are too sympathetic a species to inflict pain willingly. However, history constantly proves that men are quite eager to hurt others.Being it fuelled by ideological or tribal reasons, or just pure sadism, there is no shortage of violence in our past (and present). You just need to check the torture instruments invented throughout the centuries (and still used nowadays), to understand that no brainwashing is required to convince somebody to hurt someone else.Perhaps it does take some natural inclination, but not much convincing.. and if during WWII only 20% of soldiers actually aimed at the enemy, how come 70 million people died? Did they purposely stumble on bullets?Anyway, the plot is about a marine brainwashed by a cybernetic device called MASS into killing people with defective DNA - though it is not clear why somebody against violence would join the marines to start with....PS and if the authors wanted to make a powerful statement, maybe they should have considered religious brainwashing instead of the military - which has been done way too many times before. But I guess that would have been way too controversial and Black Mirror stops short of controversy.

Title: Coulda been better!
Comment: In the grand scheme, it's very generic, to say the least. But some revalations at the last act proved it has some nuances that are enough to make it mildly refreshing, and kinda smart, at its core. It was all about the execution itself that saved the best, the meat of the story, for the last, and utilized it as a plot-twist rather than building upon it.(7/10)

Title: Heavy handed
Comment: This review contains spoilers.The fifth episode of the third season of Black Mirror is entitled "Man Against Fire". The episode is directed by Jakob Verbruggen and written by Charlie Brooker. The episode stars Malachi Kirby as Stripe, a soldier in the military. Stripe is forced to confront his past actions after a successful raid against mutants.The episode is absolutely heavy handed in the delivery of its message. The episode has MASS implants creating illusions of mutated creatures such that Stripe and his squad annihilate them. The episode does not have much subtlety in the execution of the concept. It became apparent as the episode went on that the plot attempts this as a twist. The plot of this episode is still engaging. The plots suspense is not as engaging as the direction.The acting by Malachi Kirby deserves mention. He does a fantastic job with the role and it certainly shows on the screen. Likewise, the other supporting actors play up to par. The episode is not weak in the acting or direction.Despite the lack of surprise in the plot I still enjoyed "Man Against Fire". The episode is a solid addition to Black Mirror. I would recommend "Man Against Fire".Grade: B

Title: unique take on common trope
Comment: neat stuff, sick. not possible to properly review episode without spoilers, as tends to be the case with the series. The topic for this week is genetic engineering, eugenics, genetic diseases, and that sort of thing, probably most famously covered in science fiction by the movie "Gattaca".the initial conceit is what may be some manner of minor post-apocalypse, in which soldiers with combat-enhancing implants hunt down and kill shrieking deformed monster-people called "Roaches". Then one of them hits the protagonist with an electronic tube with green lights, and stuff starts changing for him.the big reveal is that there are no "Roaches", at least in terms of what the soldiers see; their implants directly affect their cognition (all their senses, not just sight) so that they see designated people they have to kill as shrieking monsters. they are actually killing normal civilian people who are "genetically inferior", pre-disposed to genetic deformations, diseases, illnesses, mental disorders, that sort of thing.rather than handle the situation in a soft bigotry type of way like in "Gattaca" (where these types of people are tolerated but essentially second-class citizens) or trying to gently exterminate this via eugenics programs, the people in this episode have gone a seemingly overly complicated path to exterminate people with inferior genes, while also fixing the supposed "problem" of soldiers in war being hesitant to kill their enemies, ending up going out of their way to avoid actually hitting their opponent.by literally dehumanizing their opponent, the soldiers can kill their enemies mercilessly with no lingering effects of PTSD or combat fatigue or mercy to their enemies.while an interesting conceit, the execution seems troubled, with it taking just a bit too long and in a roundabout way to get to the big reveal, and then having to have it all explained in two separate Expo Dump monologues that end up leaving a small window of interesting self-reflection followed by heaping portions of fridge logic that linger long afterwards. Some of the major issues that you think up later; 1) Only the soldiers have the implant which makes genetic inferiors look like "Roaches". Thus, the other civilians in the area know that the "Roaches" are normal people who are infected. It seems highly likely that there would be a lot more people than the one supposedly crazy religious man hiding "Roaches" in their homes and keeping them safe, and that interactions between the soldiers and the civilians would eventually lead to the realization by one side or another that the "Roaches" aren't actually monsters.2) The episode does a great job of avoiding any significant Nazi parallels, but I cannot imagine this situation they have of implanting soldiers to make them see the enemy as monsters would be universally accepted among all nations and/or fighting forces. It would seem that having one nation and/or one army going around mass murdering civilians in a European country they deem to be "genetically inferior" would not be a situation that would escape notice of other countries, who would most likely end up eventually uniting and attacking them to stop them.3) Given the level of technology they have, it would be utterly impossible to keep something like this a secret.

Title: With a great thought provoking premise and smart execution, Men Against Fire is one of Black Mirror's best
Comment: Right now, this and Be Right Back are head and shoulders above all other BM episodes for me (with 9 still to watch). I really loved this one. It's an exciting plot with a great twist that makes perfect sense, and has a rich ambiguous message. In varying ways it gets at government propaganda, the psychological effects of war, human nature, and the difficulty of resistance. Extremely well executed, and the ambiguous ending is fantastic. We know what his decision is - but what do his tears represent? Also dope to see my girl Shiv (Sarah Snook) here. This is a really great episode with much more complex and compelling moral considerations than many episodes of the show.

Title: The season's most thought-provoking episode
Comment: To me, this episode felt more like an episode of Black Mirror than any other this season. The thing I like most about this series is the way that it makes me ask myself ethical questions that I never would have thought about otherwise while I'm watching. It brings up the topic of morality relative to near future technology. That is what has been in some ways lacking from this season... until this episode. Admittedly, the episode is a little bit heavy-handed at times, a little predictable at others. But at least it was working with big ideas, putting them out there, and making me think. For that reason and that reason alone, I liked it more than any other this season.The episode follows future soldiers as they hunt down and kill genetically inferior "roaches" in some part of Europe. The subjects of eugenics, consent, and propaganda in the modern age are all brought into question by the episode.

Title: Other reviews make me quiver
Comment: First and foremost, this is a good episode, just like the rest of the Black Mirror series.To cut an extremely long and complicated story short (no sarcasm, honest) the military hypnotises (potentially implants too) voluntary recruits to the armed forces. This ensures they are viewing the human race (the damaging, disease ridden, destructive race that we are) as mutants that need to be destroyed before they destroy "us". It's a well planned out episode but merely telling a story we're more than accustomed to. Delete the lesser, power on with the stronger of the species (Hitler anyone? No?)Anyway, the episode culminates after the main guy gets shone in the eyes by a laser which the "roaches" (also known as human beings) had constructed to help soldiers see the real them. He starts to realise and rebel resulting in a showdown with the mastermind of the project. He's given an option, continue to live in a world where he'll be hunted or be the hunter and he'll forget everything he's seen thus far.The episode ends with his (presumably dead) wife running out to greet him after being dropped off at a now derelict home, which due to a quick flashback shows it used to be beautiful.The ending is open to opinion, but I think it's more than apparent (and more apparent than some of the other explanations I've read on here) that she'd been deemed a "roach" and subsequently killed by the him and the military, hence his constant torture throughout the episode.Enjoy and I hope you make similar sense.

Title: It's been done before
Comment: I'm giving this a one star because it's essentially a rip-off of a story from The Outer Limits and isn't original. In TOL episode there are people fighting each other who regularly take a drug because of "radiation", when in fact it alters their perception of the enemy so they look like monsters. One soldier ends up not getting the drug and sees the "monsters" for what they are - real people - but cannot convince his friends that they have been manipulated into fighting other humans, not alien monsters. So the story line is exactly the same.

Title: Good ideas, but poor presentation and execution.makr this a poor episode for Black Mirror
Comment: The episode begins rather strong. It made me interested in the protagonist and the overall arc. But they present too many clues for me to be surprised by the twists.The content feels spoon-fed rather than particularly intriguing. And they had a lot of ideas for this episode where the presentation could have been more mysterious. But instead it feels slow, obvious and in the end, over-the-top vindictive and cruel. I know to not expect a fun or light topic for this series. But this one took some ideas which were potentially believable with improved technology and stretched them unnecessarily to where the antagonist became unbelievably cruel for the sake of exploring how evil some technology could become. Instead the goal should be creating an engrossing story related to the potential issues of technology. This one wallows in the issues too much. Nose dive was similar.And that is what is so upsetting. In both episodes the stories have some good ideas, great acting, great sets and great costumes, but the stories aren't written in a particularly strong way to get the most out of the ideas. The ideas and work come off like a missed opportunity.

Title: Ignore All Negative Reviews! It's A POWERFUL CONTENT! And it will Show you Harmful effects of Upcoming Modern Technologies!
Comment:
I don't know why people rated this episode lowest among all those episodes available in season 3.In fact people Rated "San Junipero" episode for highest among all episodes in season 3.Ha Ha It seems like a Joke to me.This "Men Against Fire" Episode is such a brilliant episode which shows us how Neuro_Plantation could be a propaganda machine in near future generations! Especially for some Targeted Genocides. How people would be brainwash by this innovative technology. It also provided us some World War 1&2's original references, where most of the Soldiers refused to fire against each other and how shamelessly the generals tortured them to fire against Peoples; like that.This is such an Amazing plot and the Main Character Acted it brilliantly. The Screenplay, Musics, Action Sequences and horror factors all mixed up well together in this episode. So I can simply go with 9 Out Of 10 Stars for it. Coming into my Parental Guidance point- Just Avoid Watching it with anyone of your family member! It strictly contains pure frontal nudity and have some gored things as well.
You can go for this episode... Thumbs Up from my side.

Title: Black Mirror standard
Comment: I liked the military environment. Plus, unlike in other previous Season 3 episodes (except for Nosedive) the technology is crucial point of the story. Topic of propaganda and its spread via technology is, in today's "post-factual" times, highly relevant. The motive of eugenics is also up for discussion. Despite weaker last act it's stadnard BM episode.

Title: One of the best episodes
Comment: I had no idea what to expect from this episode. I was expecting people vs. zombies, but it was much more. The idea of seeing the enemy as "the other" makes it easy to kill. It is almost a reflection of what we are experiencing now. This person doesn't look like me, has a different religion, skin color, language or sexual or, therefore he is less human than me. We know, or should know, that is not the case. We are all humans. The story and lesson are thought provoking, and the acting by Malachi Kirby as Stripe was outstanding. After watching two disappointing episodes, Metalhead and Crocodile, Men Against Fire was a return to the classic episodes of Black Mirror.

Title: Yay outter limits episode
Comment:
The first moments were okay, well female power characters and weak men... Ofc Netflix, would be actually better if main character was just preparing sandwiches but ok NVM :-) I don't mind replace stereotypes but let's just put them on the equal level else it is not making that much sense and is far away from reality.
After first action you will predict the plot, what was wierd that having soldier not explain what happened or reported how it went was at least strange. Main character is definitely the type who gonna get bitten by zombies doesn't tell anyone and get back to the base full of unaware people. I was also surprised that nobody asked him for the detail story what exactly happened. Stupid thing was that they had technology to saw through his eyes - hmmm surprise. Also he was really easily convinced what army did even if roaches could do the opposite and use their technology to made them look like ordinary ppl. Tbh like the original episode of the outter limits idea is great, could have been done better

Title: We Are Our Own Worst Enemy Sometimes
Comment: This will be brief. The destiny of our world will probably be destruction because we are so out to lunch with our technology. Give access to the greatest possibilities for advancing civilization, we spend our time Tweeting and Texting and maligning. Right now we have a President whose life is devoted to attacking those who are weak and can't defend themselves. Cyber bullying is rampant. Since anonymity is a part of the game, hatred is parceled out by those who would normally be cowards. Are cowards. But this episode turns the tables. If the bad guys can get at the victims of cyber attacks, they can also get at the perpetrators of such things. The ugliness and mean spiritedness produces results unexpected. This held me spellbound and frustrated as those in power can't see their own rear ends (mistaking them for their elbows). Probably the best episode of this series.

Title: Another Bleak and Scary Misuse of Social Media and Technology
Comment: When the journalist Jo Powes writes a tough article criticizing the disabled activist that committed suicide, she becomes the most hated person in London. Soon she is found dead with sliced throat and her wounded husband becomes the prime suspect of Chief Inspector Karin Park that is investigating the case. However her new partner Blue Colson, who is expert in IT, suspects of a different reason. When the rapper Tusk mistreats live at television a young fan, he becomes the most hated person in the social media. Soon he has a seizure and dies at a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scanner and the doctors find that a drone bee is the responsible. A further autopsy in Jo Powers shows the same cause and Blue finds that the hashtag #Death to seems to be the responsible for the deaths. Agent Shaun Li from a federal agency teams up with Karin and Blue and they head to the Granular Company that created the bees trying to solve the case. Will they succeed?"Hated in the Nation" is another bleak and scary episode of "Black Mirror" showing a possible misuse of social media and technology by hackers and government. The result is impressive and shocking. The open conclusion does not give the sensation of satisfaction to the viewer that would certainly like to see Blue's revenge. My vote is eight.Title (Brazil): "Hated in the Nation"

Title: Sensational drama.
Comment: Black Mirror always manages to enthrall and entertain, and every so often it manages something verging on utter brilliance, Hated in the Nation is such an episode. It shows a craft, a skill, an intelligence, and proves that story telling is indeed an art. The imagination behind this is nothing short of genius, almost every element stuns.The fantastic story is equally matched by the superb performances, Kelly MacDonald and Elizabeth Berrington stand out for me, but everyone plays their part.I don't want to imagine a world without bees.Feature film feel and quality, this is one of the best. 10/10

Title: "We're not in control anymore."
Comment: After watching three seasons worth of 'Black Mirror' it begins to dawn that the show might very well provide the impetus for some future crime. The science and technology posited in this story sounded credible enough for a would be terrorist like Garrett Scholes (Duncan Pow) to make good on a widespread panic fueled by average, every day citizens voting for their most reviled public figure. I really liked the way the episode was laid out with the seemingly unrelated deaths of celebrities who miscalculated their public statements. Former fans of the X-Files series will make note of the use of bees to facilitate human/alien hybrids, though in this case they were mechanical ones fashioned as autonomous drones. The twist in this story was superb, as the 'victim of the day' game played out not merely representing potential daily targets, but as a mechanism to draw thousands more into the deadly final solution envisioned by Scholes. The scores of bodies revealed near the end of the episode came nowhere close to the three hundred eighty seven thousand participants identified by Blue Colson (Faye Marsay), but that probably would have been overkill (pun intended). The final scene leaves just enough to the imagination to warrant a satisfactory conclusion.

Title: Who's next?
Comment: Killer bees, newspaper columnists, social media, rude rappers. Hated in the Nation has it all. I very much like the grey sky atmosphere of London portrayed in this episode, and the sunny countryside of the witness hideout. There's much to ponder in the manner that social media can round on errant folks in a disproportionate manner.

Title: Weapons of Mass Destruction
Comment: The four episodes of 'Black Mirror' I've so far seen have all seemed to be set in a near future in which people used advanced technology as casually as we use iPads. But of all of these this story most strongly resembles straight science fiction - and far surpasses most of the nonsense currently masquerading as sci-fi on both the big and little screens.The story intelligently combines elements that have already seen service in movies like 'The Spider Woman', 'The Birds', 'The Swarm' (naturally), 'Runaway' and 'Kamikaze', satisfactorily synthesised within a narrative that highlights the very current phenomenon of the growing and unwholesome power of social media. The special effects on a TV budget more than pass muster while serving rather than overwhelming the drama as it builds up to the powerful and unpredictable conclusion we have come to expect from an episode of 'Black Mirror'.Another winner from Charlie Brooker!
Again... It's wayyyy too long and boring. Couldn't watch full episode.

Title: "Let's just shut it down all social media the whole bloody internet. Pull the plug."
Comment: The whole series can be seen as an anthology of separate short films. "Hated in the Nation" is not even short, but has the duration of a classic feature film of an hour and a half. As much as, in most cases, the duration of the episode under an hour is too short a good idea to really develop, this time an hour and a half was too much.A classic SF thriller, whose premise might be realistic for the present, if we replaced the bee-drones from this film with something that fits into today's technology, and there are certainly some that would approximately serve the purpose. However, bees here are not only a tool for abuse, but also a warning of an ecological catastrophe that awaits us, because there are fewer and fewer bees, and they are absolutely necessary and irreplaceable for maintaining the ecosystem in which we live. And only from that side, I liked "Hated in the Nation".As for the psychology of the masses on social networks and their manipulation, this topic is becoming more and more boring, and "Hated in the Nation" did not approach it in a way fresh and original enough to attract my attention. The plot twist was obvious to me almost from the beginning, so there was no effect of a surprise either. I don't like the cast, although I have no major objections to how they carried out the story. All in all, a mediocre SF thriller, good enough to hold attention, but really nothing special and quite forgettable.6/10.

Title: Thought provoking and a great concept but overlong and dull.
Comment: Black MirrorHated in the Nation (3 out of 5 stars).The plots a detective Karin (Kelly Macdonald) and her partner trying to solve a case of mysterious deaths. After the victim was already getting hated comments over the internet.This is by far the longest episode in the series. And it was the slowest and kind of boring. It has an interesting plot and the concept that takes place in the near future with technology without giving away spoilers. The theme of having a bad reputation over social media and how it can affect you in person with how people see you. Which can also be relatable.The direction feels different compared to other episodes. This definitely feels like one of those crime solving shows with the character being reviewed in court. And going over the events that lead to the court. The twist does leave you feeling unease. But the episode is slow moving.

Title: Season Three
Comment: This Third Season of Black Mirror brings forth the best batch of episodes yet (upped to six from the usual three of the first two seasons).Building off the spectacular "White Christmas" that closed out season two, Season Three delivers a slate of episodes in which only one ("Shut Up And Dance") I considered subpar. All the rest are entertaining (at worst) or intensely thought-provoking (at best).Two episodes that really stand out:-"Nosedive", in which Bryce Dallas Howard stars as a woman totally controlled by her social media feed.-"San Junipero", which I can't describe much at all without succumbing to spoilers, but is my new favorite Black Mirror episode so far. I believe this episode won awards for its writing.I think the bottom line with this Third Season of Black Mirror is that it really ups the overall quality of the season from beginning to end. Whereas previous seasons really varied in quality, this one upped the floor (and even raised the ceiling with San Junipero).I'm more excited to continue the Black Mirror journey than at any other point so far in watching this show!

Title: The Bees! They're In My Eyes!
Comment: It's not the bees' knees, but it's nice as synthetic honey.

Title: Nicely done investigation with a touch of creepy Sci-Fi
Comment: I welcomed the "thriller" format of this episode The police inspector played by Mcdonald has the sarcastic edge of somebody who's seen it all and does not want to get emotionally involved. The robotic bees were a nice touch, although the extinction scenario not so much..The idea here is that "haters" on social media should be punished, which would not be a bad thing. We probably all know what is like to receive offensive messages from anonymous strangers, sometimes just because of a casual remark on a social platform. This episode follows the concept of "White Bear", but it is way less creepy. Once again, the focus is on the people more than on the technology. Excellent way to end this series.

Title: Not the bees
Comment: Hated In The Nation is pretty straightforward for a Black Mirror episode. Very entertaining even if I didn't like the last 3 minutes.

Title: Best episode of season 3
Comment: Working in the field I can appreciate the tech behind this and it was a great comment on the deleterious effects people can have en-masse on social media but unfortunately the end left me cold which loses it a point or two.They should have left it with the guy shaving his head and leaving but instead they had to stick in the obligatory USA style ending to roll things up instead of leaving the viewer to think!Apart from that it was well shot but the overuse of the "f" word is very tedious and quite unnecessary and really could do without it and the whole police, government and investigators were made to look like some pastiche of CSI Miami which was a bit laughable at times!It is quite prophetic episode if you just check this link - spooky eh!http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/technology-41363465/bees-go-online-in- manchester

Title: Best episode of the series!
Comment: After a couple of dubious episodes Nosedive and Playtest that started off Season 3, neither of which I liked due to the painfully annoying main characters, the series pumped out a couple of classics 'Shut Up and Dance' and the highly acclaimed and lauded 'San Junipero', then a good one 'Men Against Fire', and finally wrapping up with this one HATED IN THE NATION, which I think not only tops Season 3, but the entire series. A movie length episode clocking in at almost 90 minutes, HITN is an engrossing, edge-of-your-seat, informative police procedural with a witty script and top-notch acting.Anchored by brilliant performances by Kelly Macdonald (as Det. Karin Parke) and Faye Marsay (as Det. Blue Colson), HITN methodically reveals twists and turns without insulting the viewers' intelligence with red herrings. Parke is a veteran homicide detective and Colson is a rookie who just transferred from cyber crimes. The plot follows our 2 detectives investigating a string of murders related to advanced technology known as ADI, where mechanically engineered bees are being used to kill off unpopular citizens in via the twitter-verse. The genius of this episode is how it so effortlessly combines several current relevant topics and made it all seem like this scenario is possible in the near future. In addition to the 2 leads, the acting is really sublime throughout and not a single character annoyed me or stalled the storytelling. No joke, this exciting exercise would have been worthy of a big-screen presentation. It's that good.

Title: NOT THE BEEEEEEEEEEES!
Comment: Whilst I do respect their attempt, which is mostly successful, to expand upon the concept of the fatal consequences of online hate, I think they ended up stretching it to a fault. The narrative is compelling and complex, for the most part, as well as the moral aspect in itself, but the episode failed to be constantly engaging for me due to its relatively long runtime. Still, it's a great episode overall anchored by a brilliant cinematic cinematography and strong performances from everyone involved, particularly Kelly Macdonald.(7.5/10)

Title: Feature film noir
Comment: This review contains spoilers."Hated in the Nation" is the sixth episode of the third season of Black Mirror. The episode is directed by James Hawes and written by Charlie Brooker. The episode is one of the longest Black Mirror episodes at 89 minutes of running time. The episode focuses on two police detectives in Karin Parke, played by Kelly Macdonald, and Blue Coulson, played by Faye Marsay. The detectives investigate murders that are seemingly caused by social media."Hated in the Nation" is a classic noir show. This episode follows the conventional tropes in a noir story but it is updated for the modern day. This episode felt more like a police procedural movie than an actual Black Mirror episode. I personally enjoyed this change as it made Black Mirror feel grounded. The slow investigation and build-up allowed for a more authentic story to be told. The two main leading characters played by Kelly Macdonald and Faye Marsay do an excellent job. They play the role of a veteran and rookie cop well.The main issue I have with the episode is the gaping plot hole. Once it was revealed that the ADI bees utilized facial recognition to find its targets, why could the characters not have utilized masks to assist the targets. This part of the story made no sense as the targets could have been saved.The episode is well shot and directed. For much of the episode, CGI is utilized to good effect. It made for an interesting spectacle seeing the autonomous bees in action as they honed in on their targets. The episode does not only rely on CGI to tell its story and most of it is kept light.I would recommend "Hated in the Nation". This is a solid Black Mirror episode.Grade: BBlack Mirror Season ThreeThe third season for Black Mirror is solid. This season has a great ensemble of episodes that reflect different themes and settings well. The first episode in this season is a solid look at social media and its impact on society. The series continues this theme of technology and society through the season. "Man Against Fire" had a nice commentary on the use of technology in the military. The season capped off with a near feature film in "Hated in the Nation". None of the episodes felt weak and the season is strong overall.I would recommend the third season of Black Mirror.Grade: B

Title: saw it coming
Comment: figured it out within half an hour. as subtle as a hammer. something about the way it handles the subject of "don't be a dick online" seems so horribly inept and unclever, like a condescending anti-drug campaign that ends up making people want to take more drugs, just out of spite.given how hit and miss black mirror has been with these sort of moral message themes, they could have approached this idea of an "outrage culture out of control" much more convincingly and entertainingly instead of tying it in to a dull, badly-paced tech-y murder mystery complete with robot bees being hacked and made to swarm in a goofy CG sequence

Title: #hastag fly squatters at the ready.
Comment: This one is A clever idea , by now the franchise is inter interlinking with other episodes/stories wont give away the spoilers but just keep your eyes peeled always and ears open.I could see the ending coming pretty much half way through this but I'm now watch for about 4th time...its black mirror after all.This might normally get higher than 8 from me but I'm rating as a franchise so I gave this one 8. I love the fact that although Netflix took over from Channel 4 it didn't all go across the pond.I hate wasps even more now.There as yet to be an episode I don't like and this is the only one so far that ends with...well I cant say otherwise it be a spoiler.As with nearly all BM you can watch any story in any order. This feature length ain't a bad start. Give it a go, theres better to come.

Title: A short review of "Black Mirror" Season 3
Comment: "Black Mirror" (2011) remains the best science fiction show on television; I'd rate the six-episode third season a perfect 10. The show continues to succeed at every level with its story concepts and their execution. And I think it's actually getting better.It's getting darker and harder hitting, too. I'd guess that this season's blackmailing-hackers episode ("Shut Up and Dance") would be the one that the majority of viewers find the most disturbing. For some reason, the man-vs.-monster story of "Men Against Fire" is the one that really got under my skin.I was surprised to learn that nearly all of "Black Mirror's" episodes are penned by series creator Charlie Brooker. I'm still surprised at how many clever ideas and lean, smart scripts could spring from one writer. I was so impressed that I looked Brooker up on Wikipedia -- but was surprised to discover I'm unfamiliar with nearly all of his other work. The one exception is "Dead Set" (2008) -- the truly fantastic British zombie horror miniseries that I've been recommending to friends for ages. That makes sense.Anyway, I am fully and happily converted to "Black Mirror's" cult following, and I enthusiastically recommend it to people who ask about it. (The show's popularity is still growing -- I believe it appeals to the same kind of fans as those who flocked to the various iterations of "The Twilight Zone" and "The Outer Limits" of generations past.) But I might actually suggest that newcomers begin with the second or third season, rather than the first. Season 1 is terrific, but it's three episodes are more subtle and thematic, while the latter seasons follow a more conventional story structure that might better appeal to more mainstream audiences. (They have more satisfying twists and emotional payoffs, too.)And a quick caveat -- I'll reiterate that this show is indeed dark. There is a strictly human element to most of "Black Mirror's" twists that is intended to surprise the viewer by provoking anxiety or dread. For a show that relies on technological story devices, it succeeds even more with its old fashioned psychological horror.

Title: A dark, engrossing mystery ends a shaky season on a strong note.
Comment: In my opinion, the third season of Black Mirror has been very shaky. Each episode has had its own major attributes and its own major flaws. This one is the least flawed of the season. And while it may not quite achieve the moral intensity of "men against fire" or the interpersonal chemistry of "San Junipero", these elements were strong enough to be serviceable, and much better balanced with each other. As a result, this is the most polished and watchable episode of the season.The plot focuses on the investigation of the mysterious death of a hated journalist. While this starts out as a commentary on the social media age, it gradually builds in more futuristic elements until it is full-on science fiction horror. I was pleasantly surprised by just how dark and terrifying it got by the end of the episode. This was the right episode to put at the end of the season, and it is probably the strongest overall.

Title: Now that was a unique one.
Comment:
I think whatever was the bad parts of the episode but it never bored me at all. It was a fully thrilled detective sci-fi episode. I loved the bees.
What was interesting was the fact that just a hastag created all the problems and it was fair to say that if you wish someone to be dead, then you are a criminal mind too.
What struck me was the fact that why a website can't control just a hastag which is reason of many deaths.

Title: The last AND the least: A brilliant episode which got killed by .... SPOILER ALERT!
Comment: 'Hated in the Nation' starts of like most Black Mirror stories: about a new technology that has gone bad, in this case, a social media app which is a thinly disguised Twitter. A Trollumnist made some truly horrendous remarks in her column about a vulnerable group (that is in reality also the Trollumnists formula: crap on the weakest members of society to invoke outrage and self-righteousness from the other side) and got huge crowds reacting very negatively to her. She's found dead later, and when an equally hated rapper ("rapper" really gives it away: white middle class favorite Public Enemy no. 1) gets killed, it turns out they both got killed by Autonomous Drone Insects (ADI) or robot bees. These robot bees were manufactured by the millions to replace real bees who've gone extinct. Here is the first hole: the story focuses on Britain, and it doesn't, like it should have done, lampooned the reason why the UK couldn't import bees from the EU (oh wait ... Brexit?)Now it appears that someone hacked the access to control these bees and is sending them to kill anyone who is top of the list of unpopular people, determined by a hashtag #DeathTo. The whole process seems fully automated. The two female cops (one cyber expert, the other a veteran) who research this, find out who's behind all this and try, together with the company which invented the bees, (great example of why certain things should NOT be left to companies) to counterhack the hacker for control of the robot bees. They seem to have done that, and then the cyber saffy cop thinks they are walking into a trap laid by the hacker: the actual target is not the people on the list, but the people who have been VOTING to get people killed, or, 387,000 citizens. In typical government and Alpha male fashion, the government spook decides to not heed the female cyber cops warning and pushes the button (that should give them back control over the robot bees) anywayNeedless to say, the female cyber cop was right, it WAS a trap and 387,000 people die, killed by robot bees. Until this point and including the scenes of the hearing this episode is STILL good. But then apparently the writers just can't help themselves and attach some "Crime Does Not Pay " ending to it all. The Cyber cop has found the hacker and seem to be going to kill him in a Silence of the Lambs "I'm having an old friend for dinner" open-not-open ending. Which spoils everything! Because the lesson of Black Mirror has been consistently that technology leads to bad outcomes. And a revenge-good-girls-win-in-the-end kind of nauseating Happy Ending .... spoils all that. The message SHOULD have been: don't be mean on twitter just cos you're anonymous, it's gonna backfire ... badly. But now the message is: horrendous criminal gets whats coming to him, so all's well that ends well. I truly hope Charlie was forced into this by Netflix and not conceived the ending himself, because I would lose all respect for him as a writer. In their zeal to have not everything bleak (San Junipro, Be Right Back), the writers have truly Disneyfied this episode. What a pity, it's just 3 minutes too long.4/10 The Melancholic Alcholic.

Title: A ridiculous premise...made enjoyable.
Comment: The best thing about "Black Mirror" is the originality of the story ideas. "USS Callister" is certainly original! The only real problem is the premise, though very original, is utterly ridiculous. My advice is just suspend your disbelief and go with it!The show is about a very passive-aggressive man, Robert Daly. Although he's extremely shy and easily pushed around at work, he's developed an ultra-bizarre way of exacting revenge and feeling all-powerful. He's designed a huge multiplayer game but is apparently so brilliant that he's able to create exact copies of his hated co-workers and he torments them in this alternate reality. Here, Daly is the captain of a space ship (VERY MUCH like "Star Trek") and is these co-workers don't do EXACTLY what he wants, he tortures them. Eventually, a new co-worker is recreated in this world...and she's determined to defeat him even though he seems to hold all the cards.Just ignore the voices in your brain that say "you can't do THAT" and the like. Of course you can't...and it's a fantasy show. So sit back and enjoy...though the show is occasionally tough to watch because Daley is indeed a sadist.

Title: How's That Again?
Comment: Maybe I'm not smart enough to figure out what happened. Yes, I understand that an unhappy loser has found a way to enter his own video game and play god. What I don't think is sufficiently explained is the science behind it. I know he created characters from DNA samples and he cruelly uses them, but how is this supposed to work, even as speculative fiction? This series is drenched with cynicism about the future of the world. This episode seemed too comic.

Title: A Big Joke with the Use of Technology and Star Trek
Comment: The technician Nanette Cole arrives at the Callister Company to work with the lonely and shy nerd Robert Daly that she worships, who is the owner with his partner Walton. They are working in the update of the game Infinity created by Daly that must be released before Christmas. Soon Nanette learns that Daly is a patsy guy and the coworkers mock him. When Robert overhears her conversation with a colleague, he catches a cup of coffee in her garbage and brings home. Nanette awakes at an Enterprise-like spaceship called USS Callister and learns that her colleagues and she are crewmembers and Robert Daly is the fearless captain of the ship. Further, he controls their lives with infinity power and they shall obey him to avoid tragic consequences. What will Nanette and her friends do?"USS Callister" is a big joke with the use of technology and Star Trek. The creative plot is well-written and well-resolved, with an optimistic conclusion for the USS Callister crew. It is also interesting to see the dark side of a human brain since Robert Daly has two opposite personalities that uses his knowledge to live a totally different life at home. My vote is nine.Title (Brazil): Not Available

Title: A great start to Series 4
Comment: When it started I could feel my high expectations fading, I thought I was in for a bad Star Trek spoof, but within minutes I realised that they'd come up with the goods in this episode. The plot is extraordinary, so incredibly imaginative, a wonderfully slick script and great performances all round. In the better episodes of Black Mirror you get absorbed in the crazy world, in this one I truly did buy into it. So imaginative, so good. 9/10

Title: "Hold on, I think my pizza's here."
Comment: Wow, not a lot of love on this board for 'USS Callister'. I thought it was a blast right out of the box, knowing that the opening sequence was some sort of spoof that was going to be carried out through the rest of the story. As a fan of the original 'Star Trek' series, I enjoyed the characters and the similarities they shared with their Enterprise counterparts from the 1960's, especially actress Michaela Coel's resemblance to Nichelle Nichol's Uhura. The distracting thing though, was Robert Daly's (Jesse Plemons) resemblance to Matt Damon. That's who I kept thinking whenever he came on screen. The story itself you could poke holes through left and right. It doesn't make sense to me that a digital clone of someone would have that person's memories or share the same hang-ups their human counterparts would have. In service to the story though, this was an entertaining exercise that deviated from the often bleak, dystopian world that makes up much of 'Black Mirror'. The writers even managed to insert some sci-fi gobbledy-gook that I enjoy so much, such as when Captain Daly ordered the Callister into that asteroid gas cluster charged with ionized pyron particles, thereby increasing the ship's photon intensity. Too bad about the plasmorthian crystal though, they never did manage to get hold of it.

Title: The Captain, the CEO, the programmer and Kirsten Dunst
Comment: Kirsten Dunst has a blink-or-you'll-miss cameo in this provocative season 4 opener of Black Mirror. In real-life Kirsten is engaged to Jesse Plemons.Much has been written about USS Callister. It has over 47,000 iMDB votes, and almost 150 user reviews, which I think is the most part from Bandersnatch. I must confess I've never watched Star Trek, but I can still relate to the sly wink and a nod references to Gene Roddenberry's classic.I have a sense that the reviews for USS Callister fall into two broad camps. Those who see it as a parable of the me too movement. Then there are those who are drawn to the "muscular" captain and his humiliation of his "subjects" and political incorrectness and all that.
As the beginning of new season it was pretty well delivered. Plot was interesting,there was some cruelty but for me it wasn't enough ending was perfect really enjoyed watching it.

Title: Cogito, ergo sum
Comment: "USS Callister", the episode that opens the fourth season of the "Black Mirror" series, came from a good idea for a premise, but the premise is poorly set and realized even worse.I like spoofs on the Star Trek franchise and its fanatics. I like the set design and the overall retro approach to the aesthetics of this episode. I also like the futuristic technology of virtual reality, although practically the same thing has already been seen in the episode "San Junipero"."USS Callister" raises moral issues related to artificial intelligence and (mis)use of modern technologies, typically for "Black Mirror". It also brings us a study of the character of a macho bully, behind whose self-confident machoism and misogyny hides a difficult form of a lower value complex of a Trekkie nerd, a frightened and immature, but successful programmer and owner of a VR company.On the other hand, it is all very badly packaged in a story that had the potential for a serious and tense mindfak drama, and it turned out to be linear and unconvincing, like a children's picture book. Even the victory of good over evil in this story does not work well, because almost all the characters are more or less "villains", and our "heroes" are in fact villains overly punished for their "crimes" by a mentally ill person, who also does not deserves an end like this.Although promising at the start, the episode "USS Callister" has developed into a story full of completely incredible logical and technological holes and omissions, which we might be able to ignore for the sake of convincing characters with whom we can connect, cheer for them and fear for their destinies, or for the sake of strong moral. But when the "heroes" of the story are two-dimensional and just as repulsive as the "villain", and the moral message crap itself, then the only thing that can pull out a film is a powerful and well-written story, which this one certainly isn't.Technically well done, with an interesting aesthetics, but hollow in both the plot and the essence, this "Black Mirror" episode left me with a bland taste in my mouth.6/10.

Title: Visually exciting and fun.
Comment: Black MirrorU.S.S. Callister (4.5 out of 5 stars).The fourth season of Black Mirror opens up with an exciting, thought provoking, and fun episode. The concept pays homage to the old Star Trek series. Robert Daly (Jesse Plemons) created a virtual reality gaming network. Were he lives through as a Captain of a USS Callister spaceship with his crew. Following on voyages and missions. Except, the crew members he has a copy of their consciousness from the real world people who are his coworkers in his company. Which in reality, he is treated poorly. But in the simulated world he can do whatever he wants. While acting up his favorite tv show called Space Fleet.The plot is thought provoking, and plenty of fun. The episode does get dark with the main character making you feel unease. And very much creepy. It does feel like a character study with a character being bullied at work. And how if he has the capabilities on doing whatever he can without rupercussions. Living in his own world.The twist at the end is thought provoking without giving away spoilers. The cinematography work and the camera angles does try mirror image how J.J. Abrams Star Trek movies are. The visual effects are not bad for a tv series. The costume and set designs plays like a 1080s sci fi series. It is one fun episode.

Title: Great episode with only minor creepy elements
Comment: Great start of the new season. A not too gloomy episode targeted on Sci-Fi from the 60's and the nerds who love it. By chance I just finished watching the second series of Fargo and I was pleasantly surprised to see two of the main characters in different roles.Piemons is Robert Daly, the lonely nerd managing a high-tech company by day and brave spaceship captain by night.Milioti, looking healthy and strong, is Nanette Cole, a contemporary woman who ends up trapped in the spaceship as an hapless, miniskirted girl from the 60s.Don't expect a Star Trek episode, even if at the start it looks a lot like that.

Title: A really fun episode
Comment: This one isn't really made to make you think and question your life. It's just an extremely entertaining, well made piece of television. It's very good.

Title: Brilliant story, brilliantly told
Comment: A novice games coder is trapped in the nightmare world of the genius she idolizes, and must use her smarts to liberate herself.Can't praise this enough. Lots of IMDb reviews have complained about plot holes, but they miss the point that without suspension of disbelief there is no drama: if a digitized clone is not sentient, it has no connection with the character we care about. Please ignore those reviews, because they were written by Robert H. Daly. If people want to see a plot hole let them look at the Last Jedi's treatment of an unsuited body in space, and compare that to the emotional description of the same given in this episode of BM.Apart from that, this is Brooker at the height of his power, with help from a wonderful co-writer: love of genre leading to satire of society, with a rich icing of terror and humour. Plus lovely plotting and pace.I would say lots more about the wonderful actors and set design etc, but IMDb has now made it practically impossible for me to access my review of the Twilight Zone episode from 1961 It's a Good Life, which I thought probably influenced Brooker's concept for Callister. Now I'll never know, and I can't see the point of reviewing on IMDb anymore. But had to do this last one, before the Mirror turns completely Black.

Title: I know some Black Mirror fans don't like this episode, but I do (I love it).
Comment: USS Callister is biting commentary on 'reboot-culture', gaming, internet trolls and nostalgia as a whole. This episode is almost like a loot-crate for sci-fi fans who grew up on this stuff (show runner Charlie Brooker did); you can see callbacks to things like the original Star Trek (obviously), the 2009 film reboot, Battlefield Earth, The Matrix, Toy Story, Interstellar, and even Guardians of the Galaxy (at least certain images did that for me). It evokes all these classics while telling a memorable tale in this anthology series masterpiece, showing how 'playing-master' over your subjects, even digital ones, is not necessarily a good thing.For me, this episode is probably the season-best alongside Black Museum and Hang the DJ. Black Mirror is innovative television at its best.

Title: Immensely entertaining
Comment: Even though Seasons 3 and 4 of Black Mirror have been rightfully accused of being more mainstream due to the Netflix streaming and requiring a wider appeal to continue going, mainstream isn't always a bad thing, and there's no further proof of that than this premiere episode of Season 4 called USS CALLISTER, an infectiously entertaining episode that pulls off the amazing feat of being both hilariously funny and darkly terrifying all within the same scene in several moments in the episode. With the obvious parody of the original Star Trek 60s series, there's also an homage to the classic Twilight Zone episode "It's a Good Life".CALLISTER tells the tale of Robert Daly (superbly played by Jesse Plemons), a computer genius and CTO of a tiny startup company specializing in virtual reality gaming. Daly is an extreme pushover and introvert, allowing everyone in his company to walk all over him, even though he's the 2nd-in-command. The CEO is Walton (excellently played in scene-stealing fashion by Jimmi Simpson), who implores Robert to be more authoritative to his employees. Daly seems like he's about to crack his introverted shell when a new hire coding phenom Nanette Cole (solidly played by Cristin Milioti), who worships Daly because of his tech expertise. Daly develops an immediate attachment to Nanette, but like everyone else, she eventually shuns him due to word of mouth around the company. So Daly in his own way takes action against his insensitive office cohorts.CALLISTER, while very funny, also has several moments of surprising power, especially as embodied in the performances of Plemons and Simpson. Although she plays a large role and her character was believable as quirky hacking geek in the real world scenes, I don't think Milioti really stood out in the Callister gaming scenes. Her humor felt a bit forced, although not enough to really take me out of the story due to the pace being relentless. The supporting cast (Michaela Cole, Billy Magnussen, Milanka Brooks, Osy Ikhile, and Paul G. Raymond) is also wonderful and nails their parts. A really strong way to start off Season 4.

Title: Crikey
Comment: Who in the crap can think stuff up like this??? Man what a great episode and totally original concept. Kudos to the writers for having a crazy ass imagination!!! If you havent watched this episode definitely hit the play button!!! One of the better episodes no question about it

Title: First one i watched and still 10/10
Comment:
I could write an essay or i could just write
Black Mirror Awesomeness, yep i will stick with that . Soild 10

Title: Nice one.
Comment:
Entertaining, enjoyable and thrilled with a proper sense of story. The best part was how cruel a man can be when this society rejects him.
And yes that technology was simply against the rights, I mean how can you trap someone maybe not a living one but still fully conscious and aware. Whatever but now they are free.

Title: Good idea, flawed execution
Comment: A Star Trek parody in Black Mirror is weirdly interesting. The story is fairly simple: genious nerd with no social skills tortures copies of real people in a VR game.The parody part works pretty well, but the show correctly doesn't dwell too much on it. It focuses instead on the "trapped" crew's efforts to escape. Which is where things go a bit wrong. First of all, the story has pretty big holes, unbecoming of Black Mirror's usual attention to detail. For example, Daly snaps his fingers and transforms others into monsters, has absolute control over the game, but...has to chase the ship. Secondly, it treats Daly as the bad guy, which isn't so strange, after all he is creepy, but pretty much ignores that the others are even worse (except for Nanette, who serves as the vehicle to 'prove' Daly is bad). It's not a question of who wins (the ending is also very un-black mirror like in terms of convenience), but of...I don't know, poor prioritisation maybe.

Title: Too much unnecessary swearing and bad language
Comment: The episode itself was okay. I liked the story idea. However, there was a lot of bad language in spots that I felt were just unnecessary.

Title: The mirror universe of Galaxy Quest
Comment: With overtones of 'I Have No Mouth, and I Must Scream' by Harlan Ellison this was a superbly written - produced and acted episode.Whereas in Ellison's apocalyptic masterpiece a computer called the shots - here it was a human although it was hard to tell the difference.So what happens when you're a bit of a bullied geek in the real World? Well you create your own Universe where you're in total command and have God like powers to bully digital versions of chosen employees from your company.Perhaps we've all imagined ourselves in an alternative World - free to do as we please - well almost for in this World the poor captives had been given the same tools as Action Man to procreate - a good example of how to make things that can't proceed smoothly.Could it ever happen? Well media giants are collecting more and more data about us - and already you can leave a digital version of yourself - but can a digital version achieve consciousness? Well we'd certainly would be going to where no one has gone before - and with a limitless digital galaxy to explore I'm sure our digital selves would have a whole lot of fun.

Title: Where is Callister TV spin off
Comment: I don't remember something like that happening in television before... Black Mirror came up with such brilliant, dark , amazing and funny concept that this episode alone could be turned into an entire TV show... The target audience of this show are Trekkies, gamers and mmorpg players... Yes EVE online / Elite Dangerous / Star Citizen I am looking directly at you... If you know any of the titles above I am surprised you are reading this and did not start watching yet...

Title: Helicopter parenting gone amok....
Comment: What I enjoy about "Black Mirror" is that many of the episodes look at modern technology and anticipate their potential abuses and down-sides. In this case, the notion of being a helicopter parent is taken to an amazing level...thanks to tracking software and iPad-like devices. The story begins with a baby being born and all seems well. But when the little girl later walks off and the mom is panicked, she picks an unusual way to protect her child...she has a chip installed in her called 'Arkangel' and it tracks her. But the chip can do much more. It can actually filter out negative images and content...and the mother decides to use this as well. So, instead of seeing blood and violence and bad behavior, the child just sees pixilated images and cannot hear the awfulness. Sounds like a great idea, huh? Well...as the child grows, it's like having NSA inside her head...and the repercussions are awful.The most interesting thing about this story is that it was directed by Jodie Foster (yes, THAT Jodie Foster). This, along with some impressive location shoots in ensuing episodes shows that this show has found an audience! As for this particular episode, while it's not among the best, it is quite disturbing and well made....and well worth your time.

Title: The Die is Cast!
Comment: Once the overprotective mother has an implant installed, she has set things in motion that can only get worse. Sara, in an opening scene, chases after a cat and her mother becomes obsessed with protecting her. She has kind of iPad that can be used to check her heart rhythms, her nutrition, and most of all, what she sees. The kicker is a device that blocks anything that may be traumatic, so the girl grows to adolescence having a totally sheltered life. When the plug is pulled, she begins to experiment like crazy with her peers. Soon the mother resurrects the device with horrible consequences. The episode is really hard to watch. The mother is really the central character in that she can never accept her daughter being on her own.

Title: Lack of Privacy
Comment: Marie is an overprotective mother of Sara since she was born. When Sara is a little girl, Marie loses her in a playground and decides to experiment a new technology to control what Sara can see or not and track her, implanting a chip in her. When Sara is a teenager, Marie promises to remove the parental controls from the device and put it aside. One night, Sara stays until late hours making love with her boyfriend Trick in his van by the lake and Marie restarts the device, seeing what her daughter is doing. What will Sara do when she discovers what her mother did?"Arkangel" is an episode of "Black Mirror" that makes any father or mother think of how far he or she shall control his or her kids using technology and keeping their privacy. There are smartest ways to do that not necessarily using a parental control of an electronic device, but with dialogue. The conclusion is absolutely predictable, despite of Marie best intentions. My vote is eight.Title (Brazil): "Arkangel"

Title: Parental guidance gone mad.
Comment: I'll admit to being initially underwhelmed by this one, but as it went on it got better and better, with the story becoming more and more compelling and the agenda of Sara's overbearing mum Maria becoming more controlling. With all the enhancements in technology and society's craving for more and more technical integration the real scare here is this felt like something that could perhaps be a reality one day. The arguments for and against the implant device are well balanced, you see things from viewpoints of Sara and Maria. Superb performances from Rosemarie DeWitt and Brenna Harding, and wonderfully directed, bravo Jodie Foster. Another sizzling episode. 9/10

Title: "Just throw it away. Problem solved."
Comment: Perhaps the reason this episode of 'Black Mirror' fails for a lot of viewers is because it's possibly the one that comes closest to examining a technology that could actually exist today. Let's face it, the ubiquitous cell phone with it's ability to take pictures and record what's happening in real time has changed the lives of everyone using it, some for better and some for worse. In the case of 'Arkangel', an implant of some sort provides a masking ability as well, so that unpleasant or troubling images can be blurred to the recipient of the implant. It wasn't really made clear in the story why the Arkangel project was banned, but one suspects it would be for it's invasive impact on the subjects being supervised. A very creepy affair when a someone can dial into a sexual encounter or view illegal drug use about to occur. And as always, unintended consequences can often intrude to derail one's life without any apparent warning. For once, this is a Black Mirror episode that could actually take place.

Title: Have you checked the children?
Comment: Arkangel is directed by Jodie Foster, and all credit to the location manager for giving Hamilton, Ontario, a special spot in the annals of Black Mirror. Here this episode presents helicopter parenting to the extreme (parents with prams screaming "EXCUSE ME!!!!!"). It's not a pretty sight, with the mother, Marie Sambrell (Rosemarie DeWitt) realizing she can see everything her daughter Sara (the wild teenage version played by Australian actress Brenna Harding).The ending is sad but inevitable.How far should parents let go of their kids?
Very decent episode showing that you can't save your childs from whole dangers in life.

Title: I expected much more from Jodie Foster and Charlie Brooker than the unimpressive "homage" to King's "Carrie"
Comment: A single mother is overly protective of her daughter. After the girl is briefly lost in a local park, the mother includes them in an experimental program, where a chip is implanted in the child's head. It sends the child's current location and vital functions to the parent 24/7, as well as live transmission of everything the child sees and hears, with the additional option of scrambling everything that could be stressful for the child.From the start, it is clear that this approach to parenting can not only go wrong, but inevitably have to go wrong, which makes this "Black Mirror" episode a story about bad, even disturbed parenting, more than the (mis)use of futuristic technology.A child who is unable to see and hear anything ugly, scary, violent, sexual, vulgar, is a child who cannot grow up and become able to face the everyday reality in which she lives. And when this practice continues into adolescence, counterproductiveness grows into a disaster.The premise could have evolved in multiple directions, with much potential for a powerful episode. Unfortunately, they developed it into a predictable melodrama, with a boring slow-paced story and a twist that is both predictable and so over-the-top to the point of nullifying even the little credibility that the episode had.Instead of a futuristic mindfuck drama or thriller with a strong message that makes you think, we got a lukewarm teenage melodrama, with an ending that seems to have escaped from some B horror of the eighties and a chewed-up lesson. The whole episode leaves an outdated impression, and that does not fit in with "Black Mirror".6/10.

Title: Interesting concept but boring story.
Comment:
Black Mirror
Arkangel (3 out of 5 stars).The episode follows a mother Marie (Rosemarie DeWitt) who gets very overprotective over her daughter Sara (Brenna Harding). Ever since, she was almost lost at a park when she was little. She invested in a new technology that is implanted inside the daughter's head. Which she can monitor, tracks the gps, check on her health for any hormone balances, and see what she sees.The episode does play a few interesting concepts with the Arkangel technology. Which has its benefits and downside. Which also one can relate to how society is now. Some parents were taught that kids need to have a little of freedom so they can learn to grow, and experience things and learn from it. Now, some may want to protect their children from any stressful situations. Which the device in the show can filter any stressful moments by blurring out the other persons face, or any violent situation. Or even blood. When Sara is a teenager. And goes out with her boyfriend. Which they have a sexual encounter. While the mother is paranoid and snoops on her tablet to see what she is seeing. Or notices she has been experiencing cocaine.I did feel like this episode was a little weaker than most in the series. It was a bit dull and boring. The concept seemed a little done before with The History of You episode. Were one can snoop into another persons memories. There was nothing mind bending or twists to make this episode stand out. It has an interesting concept that was done before and a plot that is a little bit decent.

Title: Possibly the worst so far
Comment: After the brilliant start, this second episode is a major downer. Possibly the worst of the whole series. A scary DeWitt, with an ugly haircut, plays Marie, a woman in her late 40s who becomes the single mother of baby Sara.IVF is my guess, because Marie does not look like the type of woman who welcomes male attention. I read somewhere Marie described as a 'young" single mother. DeWitt is 46 and looks like it. Nothing wrong with that, but "young mother" is not.Anyway, Marie one day almost loses her precious child in a playground and decides to have a chip implanted in Sara's head so that she can check Sara's location and see what Sara sees, via a tablet.Lots of reviewers claimed that it was "too easy" to foresee where the plot was heading. That's a lazy way to follow a story, just trying to guess what the plot twist could be. For me is the whole narrative that matters, with or without plot twist.What I disliked in this episode is not the predictability. It is easy to guess trouble ahead with a teenage daughter and an over-protective mother without a life of her own. I disliked: Sara's excessive bad behaviour, Marie hypocrisy and cowardice of not confronting her daughter, and the over-melodramatic ending. Not to mention the creepiness of Marie spying on her child's sexual activity and interfering with her life, without saying a single word about what is going on.In short, I disliked the whole narrative and not its predictability. I saw at the end that Jodie Foster directed and I was definitely underwhelmed.PS and yes, the actress playing teenage Sara looked older than 15 - the whole episode had a problem with age.

Title: worth a laugh
Comment:
I could easily see within the first several minutes what this episode was going for. After 4 seasons it's easy enough, as Black Mirror has the subtlety of a Trump speech at the best of times.
However, it still managed to execute a somewhat entertaining story about the perils of overprotective parents and wanting to keep a perpetual watch on their children, this time via a spying technology that gets implanted into a woman's daughter at a young age. It lets her monitor all her vital signs, as well as maintain a constant GPS monitor of her location, and even be able to see through her eyes what ever she sees.
Right away it starts going wrong as the mother uses/abuses the Parental Control filter, resulting in "violent" imagery the daughter sees to be laughably "pixelated" in real time, up to and including curse words and barking dogs. Thankfully, the mother removes this filter before her daughter can become a sociopathic mass murderer, after an incident where she intentionally cuts herself to see her blood become pixelated then smear it on her face.
As the girl grows up, it becomes a more straightforward drama of the perils of raising a teenage daughter when you're a psychotic control freak. I get the theme they were going for, but the actions of the mother, including threatening her daughter's boyfriend with either a statutory rape or child pornography charge, along with potentially poisoning her daughter by secretly feeding her an Emergency Contraception pill to terminate her potential pregnancy, makes it utterly impossible for me to sympathize with the mother in any way.I already knew from the very start that the "Arkangel" program thing was a monumentally bad idea, but didn't dismiss the episode because I know this exact sort of program would see widespread use in the real world with plenty of parents ranging from slightly concerned to paranoid and potentially abusive.the way it played out was a bit formulaic and completely predictable, but ultimately it was worth a bit of mild interest.The only major problems it had, which caused me to rate it so, was that several events which were meant to be dramatic played out in a clumsy way that made it laughable. And while I'm not a parent and so I can't fully understand the mother's mindset, I cannot imagine any (sane and normal loving) parent thinking it's a good idea to do things like secretly slip a birth control (or apparently a super-powerful morning after) pill into your daughter's drink after brute forcing your way into destroying her romantic relationship

Title: No more playing out till dark
Comment: I liked this one because of the amount of eventual possibilities that are available now and will be at some time. This goes way beyond checking your kiddies phone location etc but how many mums or moms out there would actually participate in the Arkangel if available today. I'm guessing millions and for me you can't watch this with a level head and realise that once again it's a BM protest to stay STOP! ENOUGH! we are abandoning all forms of human existence as it once was.A very sad using the phrase in many ways episode but another important part of the franchise.

Title: Could be a TV show on its own
Comment: Spoiler warning!As a teen this episode really hit me close, I can't imagine what it would feel like if my parents had also gotten a 'Arkangel' for me as a child. Well this episode answered my question. It is a good episode and would be a good concept for a TV show but I do have my complaints. The casting mostly, her daughter looks like she is going through her fourth divorce and the pace could have been a bit faster! I also found it a bit ridicilous that the mom really put abortion pills to her drink, yeah it was supposed to show her paranoia but, really? Overall a good episode. Worth the watch.

Title: Growth of an individual should be in a Natural way! Overprotection is like making individual's path hard for future problems!
Comment:
Hmm! This episode is really brilliant and definitely recommendable to all the parents. It's gives us lessons and I also support over-protection or Over-Parenting is not that effective for a small child to be self-empowerment especially during his/her growth period. Child can go in a wrong path, but that's our duty to teach them properly what's right and what's wrong in this world and it's consequences. And for God sake plz Teach every small kid about Spirituality. Tell them it's importance and Be a Good mentor for Yoga and Satsang for them as early as possible.Overall a Good episode indeed. It will directly affect into your brain and for sometimes you'll have to thing what's right and what's wrong in this storyline. Because you have to consider Both (Mom and Child's) Point of views and intentions.
Anyway 7 Out of 10 Stars from my side.
It have some violence and mild reference to sexual activities, So better to avoid watching it with family.

Title: Predictable helicopter-parenting story
Comment: The topic is civil, if somewhat predictable and boring. There's really nothing interesting or beyond average in this episode. It's not bad, just average. However, in terms of real-life it's very disturbing because the things displayed in the episode (overprotection, developmental issues as a result of overusing digital technolgoies) are already happening today.

Title: Love of a Mother
Comment: We all know that no one will love us more than our mothers, literally there is no one who will be able to love us and protect us like our mothers.But what will happen if the mother is over protective, can modern-technology destroy the pure unconditional love between a child and his mother.

Title: Not the best, not the worst
Comment: Why cast someone who's clearly 20+, as a 15-year-old? I couldn't suspend my disbelief on that one.Other than that, decent episode that, while failing to stick the landing, should provide an adequate cautionary tale.

Title: Wrong On So Many Levels
Comment:
1- This episode was mainly about "danger of having a super protective mother", not the danger of a parental control device.
2- Why would anyone have the need for inventing such a device? Children have to FACE the life's beauty and ugliness, ups and downs, cleanliness and dirtiness by THEMSELVES, everybody that is a parent should know it already that restricting a child from facing life's hardship is equal to delaying the child's maturity which makes them vulnerable to life's dangers, it's not a rocket science.
3- The device was actually useful and it helped the mother know her daughter was doing drugs and sex. 
4- If it's so well-known that underage children like 12 year old elementary school children are watching porn (alone or together) as if it's a normal behavior, it should be a warning sign to society and people must know that Internet porn is very easily accessible by their children and as a probable outcome they'll do what the 15 year old girl/boy did in the movie. I kinda felt bad for today's society and its permissive attitude towards its ugly normals.

Title: Very watchable, but it could've been so much more.
Comment: The initial premise of this episode had me filled with great anticipation for another thought provoking gem. However as the story rolled on it became as predictable as spinning a 50 pence piece on a table. It never quite got to the edge and inevitability spun to a flat and foreseen ending.

Title: Donna from that 70s show with
Comment: BORING episode....., that dog didnt even barked at her when she was passing by........, it was clear someone was instructing the dog when to bark ....in this future everyone is a hipster wearing THICK granny sweaters

Title: In the future....a small crime can easily escalate into atrocities!
Comment:
This episode, oddly, is set in Iceland and although I appreciate this change, it is odd as just about everyone has an Irish or British accent! I've been to Iceland and loved it...and cannot recall a single local who talked that way!The show begins with a drunk driver accidentally running over a biker and killing him. Instead of doing the right thing, he convinces his female passenger to help him dispose of the body.Years pass. The drunk driver has stopped drinking and is wracked with guilt over the other man's death. To try to make some amends, he wants to tell the man's wife that he is dead so she can go on with her life. He plans on sending an anonymous letter to the woman....but makes the mistake of letting his accomplice know his intentions. VERY bad things ensue...much worse than I could have anticipated. And, oddly, they get much worse due to the use of equipment that can record your thoughts and actions. How does this device and an insurance investigation lead to even more bloodshed? See the show.
Once again, "Black Mirror" looks at technology and tries to predict how it can run amok...and run it certainly does!! Overall, a very interesting episode which you should see IF you have a high threshold for violence. See the show...see what I mean.

Title: Sick Stuff!
Comment: Mia is the principal character. When her boyfriend hits a bicyclist while driving drunk, she reluctantly helps him dispose of the bike and the body. When he shows up years later, filled with guilt, she kills him and disposes of his body. But there is a technology being employed by insurance companies that allows witnesses to recall things they may have overlooked. When Mia is approached, she realizes that she is going to be caught for the murder and takes dramatic steps to cover things up. Not just dramatic but psychotic. This series has a lot of sick stuff in it and this one sort of takes the cake. One question. Are Guinea pigs reliable witnesses?

Title: The Cold-Blooded Woman
Comment: After leaving a night-club, Rob is driving through a lonely road with his girlfriend Mia when he hits a cyclist.
