Story 3 is where you start to grow to dislike Rolo Haynes, as he acts a bit shady and starts lying in his story, dehumanizing in his description while the film sequence often shows the opposite.While this story is rather dull on its own, it is the culmination of the various pieces of technology introduced in the previous two stories (the transference of pain from one mind to another, the transference of consciousness from one mind to a digital device) leading to him making a sentient digital version of an executed killer able to feel pain, letting people come to the museum to personally "execute" the digital copy in a digital electric chair, even making an even tinier digital copy as a souvenir for visitors to take home in some incoherent sadism.
Then we get the conclusion of the framing narrative, as its revealed the woman visiting the museum was the daughter of the digital man in Story 3, exacting vengeance and giving a typically Black Mirror hamfisted morality diatribe about sadism, exploitation, and buzz word outrage activists who initially rallied in support against the exhibit, then get bored and move on to "the next viral outrage", before subjecting him to some ironic revenge.
The ending was overly long and wordy, but overall it was a fun ride.

Comment: So freakin crazyüòÇüòÇüòÇ. Stick with it and give it 20 minutes. It takes that long for story to develope. Just a wild story telling ride. Awesome episode no question about it!!!

Title: Black Mirror Easter Egg Hunt
Comment: Nope the first time I watched this I had no idea of the twist. I did reckon there was something a foot as the tour progressed and the guide began to sweat and when it came to the star attraction I did take on board ... well it would become a spoiler but let's say this story was discussed in different terms from the others.But the other thing is to look out for all the stuff from other episodes so this must be way into the future in the BM timeline, I mean way into when you actually walk around but that's for you to find.One of the best episodes, like White Christmas a series of stories within a main feature story.Ten without a doubt

The episode has a few stories in one story and all the stories have a WTF moment. The shock factor of this show is awesome. Looking forward to more.

Title: Disappointing bait-and-switch
Comment: The first 2/3rds of this episode is a masterclass in compelling storytelling, everything we've come to love about Black Mirror.Then there an abrupt plot twist that throws it all away, and turns it into a tawdry, predictable little revenge piece.The take-away is that Letitia Wright is a weak, talentless hack with little screen presence or ear for accents. We saw that in Black Panther wid her Wakandan speeken like dis, bruda, and it's really not much better here.If Brooker had stuck to what he wanted to make rather than what he clearly felt compelled to make, this could have been great. As it was, I just turned it off with ten minutes to go, as Wright wrecked it.

Title: The Greatest episode in black mirror after white Christmas!
Comment: Literally it was entertaining and Fun,starting felt lite tone and then the end it was outta nowhere it was damn shocking and amazing,the references of previous episodes and the museum it was phenomenal,the music was great,the two humans living in one thing it was mind-blowing and brilliantly written!Overall it was one of the most amazing episode!

Title: Okay
Comment: So take the episode White Christmas, this is essentially the same episode but watered down big time. It was okay but nothing all that special.

Title: Endless
Comment: This is an episode that I thought would never come to a conclusion. When it did, I couldn't care less. What these guys went through was of no consequence to anyone. Getting into a dream state through a video game is possible I guess, but it just took forever to resolve anything.

Title: Virtual Gays
Comment: Former college friends and videogame fight fans Danny (Anthony Mackie) and Karl (Yahya Abdul-Mateen II) reunite many years after in Danny¬¥s birthday at his place. Danny is married with a child with Theo (Nikki Beharie) and Karl gives a state-of-art update of the former fight game to his friend. During the night, they select the former characters Roxette (Pom Klementieff) and Lance (Ludi Lin) and out of the blue they have a romance instead of a fight affecting their private lives and malehood."Striking Vipers" is one of the weirdest "Black Mirror" episodes, with an erotic tale about the virtual world affecting the real world of the two lead characters in their addiction. There are funny situations but something is missing in the intriguing story. My vote is seven.Title (Brazil): "Striking Vipers"

Title: It's been a long wait.
Comment: I definitely wouldn't say it's a favourite, but it does have a very profound message, can you fall in love with more then just the physical. It has you confused at times, as you question sexuality, love, romance etc.Some people do genuinely live in a cyber reality, where life can perhaps seem a little simpler, this episode certainly looks into the divide between real life and cyber reality.Very well acted, and well produced, I'd argue the most bizarre episode to date, but it's certainly enjoyable.It's always great to see a new episode of Black Mirror. 7/10.

Title: "That the best you can do, man?"
Comment: I just read where the series creator, Charlie Brooker, is not working on a sixth season of "Black Mirror" because we, as a society, have already become too dystopian in reality, and he feels that life is bleak enough without creating more shows that could get you even more depressed. I don't know if 'Striking Vipers' is one to get you all that depressed, but with it's gender bending plot, it's a story that could certainly have best friends looking at each other in an oddly different way. The program was probably a little longer than it needed to be to make it's point, and felt padded out with the repeated immersions into the virtual reality world of Roxette (Pom Klementieff) and Lance (Ludi Lin), and by proxy, that of the two principals, Karl (Yahya Abdul-Mateen II), and Danny (Anthony Mackie). The resolution to the story brings the best friends back to reality though, even if in unconventional fashion. This one will make a lot of guys watching it queasy enough, and if seeing it together with your best bud, might even produce an unexpected reaction or two.

Title: Politically incorrect: Danny, Karl and Theo too
Comment: This season 5 opener has a huge number of iMDB user reviews, and I can understand why. This is kind of like San Junipero but with a "Danny, Karl and Theo too" twist that gives a new meaning to open marriages and male bonding I guess. The ending is uncomfortable for some to be sure, but I guess Charlie Brooker felt confident with the reception to San Junipero.The scenes in Sao Paulo, where this episode was filmed, captures the atmosphere. Japantown is used to powerful effect.

Title: Is porn cheating?
Comment: Opinions are divided. Some consider porn to be a form of infidelity in serious relationships, while others consider it a harmless way of giving vent to oneself that no one should be blamed for.But what if the development of VR technology makes pornography interactive content that provides a complete physical experience without physical contact? This is one of the questions that the "Black Mirror" episode "Striking Vipers" asks us.However, this episode is not about pornography.The two roommates, who were actively playing a video game similar to "Tekken" or "Mortal Kombat" in college, meet again after eleven years. One started a family, while the other still refuses to grow up, and, as a birthday gift for his old friend, he brings the most modern VR version of the game that they enjoyed in their boyhood days.The game, as expected, involves a chip on the temple and completely puts you in a VR environment, where you have a complete experience of brutal fights, but without consequences for your real body. The two take the same avatars they used in college, but as one of the avatars is female, they soon discover that "Striking Vipers", in addition to fighting, provides other physical experiences.Given that they are both men, does this make them gay, even though one of the avatars is female? Is a man who uses a female avatar a transsexual? Is their virtual sex a relationship or just playing a VR game among friends? Does this mean that the married one cheats on his wife? How many men would like to live through the experience of a female orgasm firsthand?In addition to the obvious question of how much the escape from reality into virtual life is a harmless break from everyday life or a dangerous addiction, there is a bunch of questions that lead to thinking and introspection, while we wait for some shocking outcome, to which the series "Black Mirror" accustomed us. What will be the message/lesson/social critique this time?A very intriguing and controversial premise, which opens up countless possibilities for a striking episode. Unfortunately, although it is excellently filmed and acted, with good characterization and overall atmosphere, "Striking Vipers" is not going anywhere. Instead of a shocking plot twist, we got a disappointingly lukewarm compromise outcome, which leaves a bland taste in the mouth.7/10.

Title: What the actual F?
Comment: This is such a weird episode and definitely is futuristic, the person that said that is wrong! Also the person that was saying look up awkward is a genius that made me laugh out loud. I guess in the future of VR we'll have love making in video games. Probably in the top weirdest Black Mirror episodes ever!

Title: A decent start of the season.
Comment: Striking Vipers (3 out of 5 stars).It was a decent start of the season. The episode plot follows Danny (Anthony Mackie) and Karl (Yahya Abdul-Mateen II) lifelong friends. Huge gamers. As years go by, they drifted apart. Danny is married and they are trying for children. Karl is living the single life and meeting girls through a dating app. Karl and Danny attempt a Virtual Reality Striking Vipers game. Which puts them both right into action. A fighting game that looks like Dead or Alive or Tekken. When they fight in a round. Karl playing as a female fighter and Danny as a guy fighter. While in VR, one event in the game leads to another which can impact how their reality.I can't give away anymore about the plot without entering spoiler territory. But when one event happens in VR. It was literally a WTF moment. it was not anything surprising or shocking. The story was decent. Not one of Black Mirrors best storylines. It does test the concept idea of a married guy's life and how exciting the life used to be. When VR is used, every possibility is endless. It does draw the line of how far can one thing go without having any consequences of affecting the people around you.It was a slow moving direction. The episode started a bit slow. Showing Danny and his girlfriend having a role playing with their relationship. A decade later, he feels burned out with his life. Same with his wife, were she feels like she is no longer attractive to him. The script and direction is slow moving and can be boring at times.It was a fair episode. Nothing surprising or shocking with its story. The cast was good. Just a bit boring.

Title: Brilliant episode!
Comment: Wow a lot of whiny uncomfortable reviews... get a grip people, this is 2019, get over it! Brilliant writing, directing and casting. And I don't get why people don't understand the ending... y'all never heard of a "hall pass"? Brilliant, just brilliant all around. It's an honest and well deserved 9/10 from me!

Title: Gay?
Comment: Striking Vipers is one of the most awkward episodes of television ever. It's also funny. And entertaining. And good acting!

Title: Superb start and in typical Black Mirror style
Comment: After the long wait Black Mirror has returned and it didn't disappoint with its first episode. The usual clashBlack Mirror has to be one of the greatest shows in television due to its dark and creative nature. We got this in the 1st episode. Solid performances from a cast which you could believe could be a whole tv series of its own such is the great pacing and depth. As usual it explores hard and conflicting emotions as two friends struggle with feelings that they only experience in VR. Only in BM will you see such emotions and complexity play out. The two don't know how to reconcile their virtual interactions with real life, what does it really mean? Great episode and solid start.8.5/10

Title: Weird but entertaining enough
Comment: Boy I was glad I didn't watch this with my dad like usual would of been even more awkward. Interesting concept that strangely enough I could see happening if it was possible amongst many people. Could have had a more important or exciting topic/story though.

Title: Missing the point uncomfortably.
Comment:
This was obviously a weird uncomfortable watch for many who found the vehicle of delivery too obscure to get the general point, and the point wasn't that obscure if you weren't reeling from the straight guys do gay whammy.
Their relationship was internet titillation of any kind, be it bog standard porn draining the sexual energy ("I'm just tired"), and attention ("real life doesn't do it for me anymore", "I'm sorry I don't think I can", "do you mind if I finish my self off"?- pulls out screen etc etc), and video games, obviously also draining time and energy away from the real world. The gay not gay aspect was an add on which felt like it kind of overtook the whole episode and you can make of that what you will. There was insight in that concept too.
For all those crying "This isn't Black Mirror!!!" this one was as Charlie Brooker black mirror as the prime minister and the pig first episode. It was weird, thought provoking and slightly uncomfortable to watch with your mum.

Title: Beautiful story so well written. With nice touches
Comment: CHARLIE BROOKER I LOVE YOU another fantastic episode where the future meets vintage and tackles subject matter with such sensitivity. Talking dishwasher, nice little background touch along with the paper thin phones. (Not a spoiler as nothing to do with story)

Title: Starts and ends on the same shock value.
Comment:
This episode was only shock value and nothing more. The characters start off experimenting with sexuality in VR. And then the show ends with the characters experimenting with sex in vr.. The characters never experiment more or evolve or change in any way as people. They stay the same stagnant characters from start to finish. I was shocked at first...but then nothing else happened. And in the end the only redeeming part was the acting. I felt like all the actors were really in that situation..
If only we had an explanation for why the sex was better with his friend than it was with his wife or with other people... Why did the wife not play the game with her husband? If the friends had such a strong connection why was it never shown at all? I think i would have ended it with the married couple breaking up and the two guys getting married...even though they are straight in the game they can get their sexual needs fulfilled completely.

Title: It's a metaphor.
Comment: On the surface this story is one of two old friends from college getting it on in an online fighting game. Obviously the makers of the game had something like this in mind otherwise they wouldn't have programmed it in but that's just a nitpick.The real message is how technology and things like video games can matter more to us and be more "real" than what happens in real life.Is it awkward? Yes. It is. Very much so. But it's also showing us the effects of such an addiction in a way that normally we wouldn't see. It's not about two dudes getting it on in VR. It's about two dudes using VR as an escape from their real lives and indulging in a little bit of fantasy. It's not harmless. It shows the real world effects of getting too into your games.Try to look beyond the awkward. There's a story there trying to get out.

Title: Nonsense
Comment: What utter tripe. Nothing in it makes sense at all, more nonsense just to make a point

Title: 5x01
Comment: Going by the rating of this episode, I thought it was boutta be mid, but it was a very very pleasant surprise because I thought it was brilliant. The start was a bit shaky, which a lot of BM episodes are because they don't exactly have much time to set up the premise of the episode so I'm not that fussed. Once we get into it though, it really is a captivating concept. I think this episode has perfectly encapsulated the complexity of human sexuality through the use of technology without reducing it or demeaning it. Pair that with a very well written and performed marriage, this was an episode about the complexity of relationships too. A lot to manage in 60 minutes, but they managed. Watching the two men as their video game counterparts was a layered experience and it does just make you wonder. It sounds childish to say that but it genuinely does. I think one drawback is that I don't think we really saw as much of the complexity when actually inside the game but again there's only so much you can fit into an hour. Overall this was just a really believable, genuine, three-dimensional and most of all human story, which happened to also be excellently shot and scored. Out of the other romantic episodes of BM (San Junipero and Hang the DJ) I think this one is the best by far, and one of my favourite episodes of the whole show. I don't have enough good things to say about it reallyMid 9

Title: Asks yourself a question you may not answer in public
Comment:
Moralistic episode where you could debate long into the small hours what is right and what is wrong.
But at the end of the Day
This is not reality, not yet anyway ...Good soild episode.

Title: Very interesting, but it was a little slow at times
Comment: I don't know why some people hate this episode, I guess it makes some uncomfortable with its plot but I found it very interesting and engaging enough to keep me watching.The cast were all fantastic as expected but it did feel as though the episode dragged on longer than it needed to

Title: Great
Comment: Black Mirror is known for its unusual stories. Striking Vipers is a great story, odd and inventive. I don't want to say more because I don't want to spoil the fun but surely you won't get disappointed by this episode.

Title: Funny AF
Comment: This is the funniest episode of Black Mirror ever.

Title: Cool idea, weird approach
Comment: The idea of the episode is decent enough, but never really takes off. There are a few too many weaknesses in the plot, and an overall feeling that this is just not Black Mirror worth material.First of all, the whole idea that this VR faux Tekken game quickly turns into porn is arguably the most realistic BM has ever been - but the notion that this technology which just came out is so advanced that it simulates sex perfectly (even though it wasn't made for that!) is rather hard to sell. Secondly, the fact that the protagonists only want each other in the VR is rather odd - to be fair, the script does try to address the obvious question "why can't you just hook up with a gazillion online users" but does so unconvincingly, with a bland "it's just not the same".All in all, the concept here is interesting, but what you expect from Black Mirror is probably a world where everyone is addicted to VR sex, neglecting real life - not a "hah, here is a fancy way to demonstrate that sexuality is a fluid concept" story.

Title: Quite Gripping
Comment: This is a really intense presentation of a man who has come to the end of his rope. After he death of his only love, he sees the indifference of society, largely their unyielding focus on their phones and electronics. They speak in cyber babble and forsake humanness. He kidnaps a young man who works for a firm that has advanced that technology, and demands to speak to the founder. It's an incredible lesson for us all and it pulls no punches.

Title: The wow episode.
Comment: As always, every series has a wow episode, one that you watch, and say Yes! This was that episode, an hour of pure brilliant, engaging, charged and moving drama.It feels slightly at odds with the usual formula of the show, back in time (albeit only a year,) for the first time, and for once we don't get the usual forms of possible future technology, just a social media platform, similar to one many of us are used to.I thought the story was awesome, so good that two super talented names, Andrew Scott and Monica Dolan were brought in. Scott has a habit of standing out from his peers, as does Dolan, but here Andrew Scott is incredible, his performance will blow you away.It's such a relevant story for today's day and age, with a hugely powerful message.Wonderful. 10/10

Title: "Your mind may wander. Simply watch it go."
Comment: One's life can change in the blink of an eye, an immeasurable second that passes instantly, leaving unintended consequences in its wake. This was Chris Gillhaney's (Andrew Scott) fate and his curse. Having crossed his own personal line in the sand, Gillhaney knew that his life was forfeit, and didn't want it any other way. Unlike most Black Mirror outings, this is one that could actually take place in the present day (it did), and didn't rely on some future technology yet to be developed or imagined. It explores one's reliance on social media to the exclusion of all else, and when it sets up a life defining event, the impact has repercussions that resemble the ripples in a pond when a pebble strikes it's surface. The story's most powerful statement is made when the woman from the group therapy session learns the password to her deceased daughter's Persona account. As she strikes the 'enter' key to access the social media account, the sniper engaged to take out Gillhaney squeezes the trigger to end the deadlock between Chris and the police. Occurring simultaneously and in a split second, the impact of each event will reverberate in the lives of those affected on that fateful day. And yet, for even the wisest like Billy Bauer (Topher Grace), there will be no answers forthcoming, only the sad realization that sometimes things happen beyond anyone's control.

Title: Back to its roots
Comment: No video game sex in this episode, but one that gets back to the origins of Black Mirror. There's nothing futuristic about this because it's now, or ever since the dawn of social media. This episode is a slow burn that keeps you guessing until the very end.The episode makes you think about Facebook, Twitter, et al.

Title: "People don't look up anymore. The sky could turn (beep) purple and you (beep) wouldn't notice for a month!"
Comment: Chris is a taxi driver who takes rides exclusively in front of the headquarters of the company "Smithereen", which controls the largest and most popular social network (like "Facebook" in our reality), persistently trying to get in touch with some of the company's executives.When he finally thinks that the person he needs has entered his vehicle, he moves on to the next stage of the plan, unaware of how much things can go wrong. But he is persistent in pushing it through at all costs.For the first time, the episode of the "Black Mirror" series is, instead of in the future or the present, placed in the recent past, in order to further emphasize the actuality of the message it conveys. Unfortunately, the message itself is old news. Do we really need another screenplay "Don't drink/look at the phone while driving" ?! As much as this message is of existential importance, I think it does not fit in with the "Black Mirror", which, at least so far, has tried to attract attention on less covered topics and open new vistas for the potential negative effects of modern technologies.Technically, "Smithereens" is a well-done episode, with interesting characters and great acting. The pace is a bit slower, so the quite simple and linear story is stretched almost to the duration of a feature film. But this doesn't matter much because the drama of our heroes is convincing, and the tension is at a decent level. However, both in content and form, "Smithereens" is a mediocre crime thriller, not a futuristic SF drama with a shocking twist that makes you think and re-examine yourself and the world we live in, which is a feature that made "Black Mirror" famous.This would not be a problem for the viewer who sat down to watch an episode of one of the many crime series, but this is not one of them. Charlie Brooker has set high standards over the years, and "Smithereens" doesn't come close to meeting the expectations of people who have been eagerly awaiting the new "Black Mirror" episode.6,5/10.

Title: Gripping - Life is meaningful!
Comment: Great episode about some Illuminati stuff and a man struggling for the will to live! A lot of important points were made like "Barely anyone looks at the sky anymore" or the factor of social media distracting us dangerously enough for a car accident to happen. Inspirational powerful episode that's very compelling and morally/metaphorically accurate like every other episode. I love this show and always will!

Title: Relatable theme but slow moving.
Comment: Smithereens (3 out of 5 stars).Smithereens is a decent episode of Black Mirror. A cab driver Chris (Andrew Scott) kidnaps one of the interns Jaden (Damson Idris) from a Smithereens company. To seek someone out from the company. Billy (Topher Grace) the owner of Smithereens tries to help and figure out why Chris is seeking for him about his company.The episode does build a little bit of mystery with some twists. The twists is nonetheless not surprising or shocking. The theme can be related to the real world with smart phone apps being a distraction to people walking on the streets, driving, or at social gatherings. It shows that people are not aware of now and days with these apps taking most of their attention.It is a bit slow moving, and boring. The episode does end a little abruptly and vague about what happened in the end. Without giving away spoilers.

Title: I got it, but still, one of the more pointless, boring and unnecessary (of only 3) episodes IMO.
Comment: Unlike some reviewers, I got it, a death as a newsflash means nothing nowadays. But I didn't need 70 mins of useless plot scenes that were dragged out to get that point across. Yes, in today's society, we've become accustomed to daily tragedy, and we don't flinch. It's called adapting to our environment. Just like we (sadly) can't keep our eyes on the road when we get a cell message. Nothing new here, so for me a waste of 1 of 3 episodes for this year. I was expecting and wanted something new, something brilliant... not the obvious. Nevertheless, great directing, cinematography, score and acting. So it's a generous 7/10 from me.

Title: Not Black Mirror
Comment: Nothing about this episode feels like Black Mirror. It's not about technology. It's about distracted driving. Don't drink and drive, and don't text and drive. Now you don't have to watch the episode.

Title: Pretty dark
Comment: Not a bad episode, it has depth and quality. It captures the worlds obsession with social media and how it can take on a world of its own. Things escalate quickly and in the end we are not sure of the fate of the two in the car. Echoes of Alfred Hitchock where we are left to ponder our own thoughts.This was a black mirror episode that didn't have the technological clash with human emotions so a bit different but not bad.7.5/10

Title: Gripping and good but not very black mirror
Comment: I remember being wowed by black mirror episodes before this series always offering something new and innovative and whilst this was gripping and acted well it felt like it could be any stand alone drama not black mirror.

Title: Great Epidode
Comment: Very Simple Story But i like it, and Andrew Scott's Acting Was Perfect.

Title: Okay thats it
Comment: I love andrew scott but he shouldnt accept to do a part in the episode. I felt like im watching some drama thing not black mirror!

Title: Boring
Comment: Was glad when it ended. Rubbish like the whole of season 5

Title: 5x02
Comment: This was really good. Andrew Scott gave a really brilliant performance and the writing was once again excellent. This was a tense thriller throughout, until you get to the end which is when it becomes pretty heartbreaking. The protagonist is clearly unhinged and we don't know why throughout. My guess was that he showed strong resentment towards Billy Bauer for making Smithereens, but really the resentment was towards himself. I think it was great, and entirely the point, that we weren't shown who bit the bullet at the end. It's just like the woman at the start, a lot of people would've gone straight onto wherever after the credits started rolling, trying to find out who died. Maybe Charlie Brooker said, or someone just has the answer. Well that's the thing, people are gonna be looking for answers but they won't get them. I'm sure that mother didn't find any answers when she did finally log into that email, despite her constant obsession. Charlie Brooker certainly threw in little hints for people to point to in their argument for who died, like Chris constantly repeating "this is my last day" or the police who seem to be a fairly lousy shot. As other people have said, it's not really important who died. What matters is that someone died and it was all really just a tragic incident. It was another very human story just like most eps of BMMid 8

Title: Good , but is this Black Mirror
Comment:
Unusually for the BM franchise this is set today ( I think )
The frustration this guy feels I share at times I'm 47 and I feel I'm at the younger end of the spectrum of this as I see some people my age glued to phones. However my very best mates seem to have my view point on this believe it or not my very best mate as no Facebook, Twitter or Instagram just text messages for that fella.The twist reveals itself before the guy does but although like with every fictional film ever made plot holes will appear this is like a docudrama and events may have or could happen quite easily. The world as changed so much since the millennium struck in that's only 20 years. People are just so different and have been sucked in. This is trying to throw out just how bad it is and how terrible its gonna get.Top acting BTW , Enjoyed it more the 2nd time I watched it

Title: Very predictable, from start to finish
Comment: Great cast, produced very well, with some good writing, but after 20 minutes you can predict the rest of the entire episode. Even the "point/message" of the episode is pretty basic and not very thought provoking as it's something we've all seen a bunch of times before now.It's not bad, but it's not great either. A very so-so episode.Now I'm off for a poo.

Title: Just a second is all it takes
Comment: Road accidents have been scaring me these days as I see a lot of them on social media. One of the causes of such accidents is using cellphones while driving. Smithereens' theme is about that. How using social media can impact someone's life.It's one of the most suspenseful episodes so far. It's set in 2018 and it doesn't have a much inventive storyline, but it's really terrifying and I love the acting.

Title: Good watch
Comment: I always like to throw my tuppence in so no doubt I'll get a hell of a lot of thumbs down as usual.A guy, hurting and hating life has some beef with a large tech company because of a notification sent to his phone which he looked and effectively caused the accident which killed his fianc√©e.The ending is the main talking point. What was the point in talking to Billy Bauer? What was the whole kidnapping the intern all about?? But it's quite simple when you take a step back. People have obviously already noted that the whole point is how our lives have changed and how a quick notification about ongoings around us deserves a quick read then that's it. Gone. No thought until the next headline or notification. It's true our society is becoming more ignorant and less aware of the things going on around us but this doesn't mean that people don't care.My own take in the ending is that both ended up being killed for living in the 'now' and not the cyber world that we're all caught up in. They both cared about an actual person and not someone on a friend request, someone who actually mattered in real life.Some people should try taking a 10 day break from social media and mobile phones. I've done it and it makes you see things much differently.Peace.

Title: Weak episode
Comment: For being a longer black episode it's pretty stretched out. I get the message behind the episode is important and probably why it's rated so high but it's just flat and kinda boring at times. Black mirror should be better than this but then again season 5 isn't that great to begin with.

Title: Weak wankery, Brooker should have long since stepped aside
Comment: A trite, insipid and dull episode with little imagination or impact.Some spud muncher gets sad about his own choices and actions, blames other people, and is the sole architect of mass misery.Why would we root for the spavined villain of the piece? Is a question that Brooker doesn't even think to ask himself, let alone answer for us.I'd give this one a miss, there are much stronger episodes before and after it.

Comment:

Title: Well made, but uninspired
Comment: Black Mirror is technophobic. We all know that. But its view of potential future technologies has just as much been insightful, ranging from very imaginative to almost prophetic. This is hardly the case here. If Striking Vipers had a decent core idea that was left largely unexploited, now we have a very well made episode, which however is based on the most mundane, outdated, generic technophobic instinct: "argh, people look at their phones all the time". Although there is some more significant critique about the user data obtained by social media, the whole episode has the vibe of an old person complaining about smartphones - including the illusion that faceb....Smithereen's creator, Mark Zuk..."Billie Bower", is a poor visionary who got shoved aside. And all that, to pass a message as simple as "don't look at facebook when you drive" - which, frankly, is hardly worth an episode of Black Mirror, nor is it of course very profound.And it's a pity, because the rest of the story, essentially a kidnapping gone wrong, is very well done, with some funny moments (the useless advice on how to talk to a kidnapper), good performances and a touching end with what Christopher asks from Billy.The problem is, this could just as easily have been an episode of Law & Order.

Title: Interesting Premise Gone Bad
Comment: Miley Cyrus plays Hannah Montana (which I never saw) as a brig rock star, beloved by young teenagers. She has an evil aunt who is using her to pad her pocketbook, using drugs to tame her. Eventually, however, she tries to find a way out. Meanwhile, there is a doll being produced called Ashley Too, which uses the star's storage of knowledge to produce a sort of Amazon Echo Alexa. It starts out with a rather cool premise and then ends with a splat. I kind of like Miley, though.

Title: Charlie Brooker what has gone wrong?
Comment: I purposely haven't read a single review, prior to watching it and writing this, I just know that the reviews are going to be less then favourable.This is the first time the show has managed to truly suck. It's too polished to begin with, the previous one, Smithereens had a much more rugged appeal, I think the Americanisation of the show has really put it on a downward spiral. It's lost its edge, compare this to something from the first few series, it's way off.Miley Cyrus proved that she unfortunately isn't really the best candidate for a project such as this.Hanna Montana for a mass audience, I imagine teenage girls might like it, but surely that's not the audience this show is appealing to. Series 5 has been a real disappointment, thank goodness for Andrew Scott who managed to save it with Smithereens.The story doesn't work, please get this show back to its roots. 3/10

Title: "If you believe in yourself, you can do anything."
Comment: This one's a bit of art imitating life in a way, isn't it? Successful pop star outgrows the circumstances that made her famous and wants to do more serious stuff, but the manager won't allow it, hoping to mine some more gold out of her earlier popularity and success. You have to wonder how many careers ended just the same way. A lot of this episode is done tongue in cheek when you get to the Ashley Too aspect of the story, particularly when Jack (Madison Davenport) triggers the 'real' Ashley O (Miley Cyrus) in the robotic toy Ashley. It's an entertaining story unlike much of the Black Mirror dystopian world view, and probably won't appeal to the majority of the series' fans. The show's primary message though has value, even if you've heard it a million times. "If you believe in yourself, you can do anything". Even break out of a coma and put the screws to your overbearing boss.

Title: "You can do anything if you believe in yourself."
Comment: Ashley, a young pop star, has outgrown the music and image that made her famous, but she is stuck in the machinery of the pop industry, which makes her more and more depressed. When she finally takes steps to get out of that story and take control of her life, her manager does not hesitate to do anything to keep her in the system and continue to get rich at her expense.At the same time, they are launching a robotic A. I. doll inspired by our heroine, in whose memory the whole of Ashley's mind has been copied. One of the puppets becomes self-conscious and sets out to save the original.The leading role is played by Miley Cyrus, who, for the most part, plays herself. She may not be a spectacular actress, but she is quite likable and convincing. There's also Angourie Rice in the role of a shy 15-year-old girl, obsessed with this pop star, as well as Madison Davenport, who plays her older sister, a rebellious rocker. They are typical representatives of two different worlds, turbulently opposed in Ashley herself.The technological aspect of this story has already been seen in earlier episodes of "Black Mirror", and there is no plot twist, so do not expect to be surprised and shocked. Before you is a mediocre SF drama, nicely written and filmed, with good tempo and atmosphere, whose linear story naturally leads to the expected end. With a duration of about 70 minutes, it would be a decent feature film, which targets the female teenage population, but, at least in my opinion, it has nothing to do within the "Black Mirror" series.6/10.

Title: Sure this one is like a Disney version with dark aspects but come on!
Comment: This is a great episode, despite its flaws it's not that bad! Ok so Miley Cyrus sings in it and there's a teenager inspired by the music/dancing it's actually very disturbing. Powerful acting and beautiful cinematography; people need stop hating on this just because it's different! Love it or don't, it doesn't matter this one has great writing and I enjoyed it even though I'm not a fan of the music. Like said in Mr. Robot "Control is an illusion"

Title: The weakest episode out of this season.
Comment: Rachel, Jack, and Ashley Too (2.5 out of 5 stars).The third episode in Black Mirror might be the weakest in the season. In terms of dull story, boring direction, and lacking a theme. Miley Cyrus, Angourice Rice, and Madison Davenport were all great with their roles. Rice and Davenport playing sisters Rachel and Jack. Rachel is a lonely teenager and a huge fan of Ashley (Miley Cyrus). Which she is a huge pop star but has been singing the same famous song over and over. And there is a computerized robotic doll of Ashley O's personality which Rachel gets as a gift. To help her boost confidence in herself. Enough I can say about the plot without giving away details.The direction is kind of boring. It is slow moving. And it does get annoying hearing the same song from Miley Cyrus. It was a great song but it overplays itself too much. It does play a factor into its theme about how managers are obsessed on keeping the singers from playing something different. A society that loves the same routine over and over. The idea of change plays a factor in the episode.I did find this episode to be quite forgettable when it comes to story. There was nothing surprising in the episode besides feeling like a lifetime channel movie.Overall, Black Mirror season 5 I will have to rate 3 out of 5 stars. This may be the weakest season out of the others. The stories feel dull and forgettable. It is lacking the creativity the previous seasons had. It does leave some room for you to wonder about the concept idea behind each story.

Title: Season 5
Comment: Because of the complexity of the interactive film "Bandersnatch", this fifth season of Black Mirror was truncated to three episodes instead of the six that comprised previous seasons. While perhaps not as pitch-perfect as the season or two that preceded it, Season Five still provided some mind-bending, thought-provoking tales.The first episode, "Striking Vipers", is an examination of virtual reality and the types of relationships it might foster. Despite perhaps losing a bit of steam down the home stretch, I still found the concept fascinating, as it brings up some very prescient conversations about the nature of both reality and sexuality.After that we get "Smithereens", which is pretty easily the best effort of the bunch. Riffing on ride sharing services as well as social media obsession, this episode is a harrowing tale of how technology has the power to devastate a life as well as enhance it. For fans who enjoy the "deep thinking" episodes, this is the one that will stand out.Finally, "Rachel, Jack, and Ashley Too" is clearly the "out of left field" selection. Starring Miley Cyrus, it examines (in what could be a sort of Cyrus bio in and of itself) micro-management of pop stars (as well as the physical pop music itself) and how much control can be had over the molding of one's image. I'd consider this to be the weakest episode of the bunch, but even then it isn't horrible. It gets a little cartoonish towards the end, but still touches on some key components of the music business.One of the fascinating comparisons I made from Season Five is to CBS' new Twilight Zone reboot. Whereas that show felt preachy and wildly uneven from the word "go", Black Mirror actually does capture the spirit of Rod Serling-esque science fiction think pieces that also resonate socially/culturally. While "Bandersnatch" gummed up the works a bit and reduced S5's overall output, show creator Charlie Brooker managed to still craft some intriguing tales. If more episodes are in the coffers, I'd return in a second!

Title: I want an Ashley Too too!
Comment: Wow, after watching a long, boring and hardly Black Mirror-ish episode 2, this one was a sheer blast! Definitely Black Mirror-ish and one of, if not the funniest of the entire series!This was a non-stop entertaining story, perfectly paced, and a fun ride start to finish, that the 67 minute length just flew by.Sure it wasn't anything brilliant, and it was perhaps targeted to a younger demographic, but for being 53 yrs old, I loved it! Miley Cyrus nailed it! I can't think of anyone that could have been cast better.Maybe this wasn't for everyone, but all you wannabe critics giving this 1's and 2's need to give your heads a shake and learn how to review a film. Click on my username and read my bio to learn how to do so.Directing was perfect. Cinematography on point. Clearly the writing was awesome. Score/Soundtrack amazing - hell ya ü§ò Nine Inch Nails ü§ò performed by MC!I have to say, this episode is one of my favs that I will remember for a long time. 100% entertaining and funny! After a lame episode 2, BM has redeemed themselves!Now I want an Ashley Too too! It's an honest and well deserved 9/10 from me.

Title: Not all bad
Comment: This didn't seem so much a BM episode but more a mature teenage thriller film with a happy ending. It's not because I can't stand Miley Cyrus that I'm passing criticism but I think after the hiatus they could have come up with a better episode. This should have never left the shop floor and a better celebrity could have been used.Still a good concept but BM often goes even further on what is possible. This is what made the show great. This small season is one of BMs weakest. The first episode about Vipers was clearly signature BM and the best. It didn't improve after that. 7/10

Title: >Phew<
Comment: Such a good episode. Not a big fan of Miley Cyrus, but this must have felt cathartic. After two really lame first episodes in the 5th season, this is the Black Mirror, as I like it. Great concept. Great cast. Great execution. It doesn't have to be dark, it just needs to turn the technology/human equation on its head. I give this episode an 8 (great) out of 10.

Title: It's quite good really
Comment: By black mirror standards like the series as a whole it's no epic but it's perfectly entertaining and felt like a bit of a paradox of Mileys life herself pre and post Hannah Montana. Not very black mirror but as a stand alone episode I still enjoyed it enough without being blown away.

Title: Thought it was superb
Comment:
After being very disappointed with Season 4 of Black Mirror and uplifted by the brilliant special interactive Bandersnatch event episode, I was really looking forward to Season 5 in part because of the limited number of episodes (only 3), which is actually a callback to the first 2 seasons of the show when it was just a British TV series, but also because Bandersnatch made me think the showrunners were back to telling compelling stories and I thought both that special event and Season 5 have been a great return to form. I'm honestly baffled at all the negativity. People need to REALLY go back to Season 4 and pay attention to some seriously horrendous acting in some episodes (talking to you female lead of USS Callister and virtually every actor in Black Museum). Whether Season 5 measures up to the first 3 seasons is up for debate, but there is just no way that Season 5 is worse than Season 4!And, for me, as provocative as 5x01 was and as brilliant as 5x02 was, my actual FAVORITE episode from this season was this one, RACHEL JACK AND ASHLEY TOO, starring singer Miley Cyrus, delivering a surprisingly persuasive performance as a pop star suffering from a major identity crisis and depression, which may very well mimic her own existence on some level. And I went into this episode worried that Cyrus wouldn't carry her weight, but in fact, she pretty much stole the show, although this episode was pretty much her show. Cyrus basically essays 2 characters: her scripted fake onscreen persona Ashley O versus her true self, which is mostly embodied in the form of a cookie implanted inisde her mass-produced doll Ashley Too. Another important character to Ashley's subplot is her manager and Aunt Catherine (played with detached malevolence by Susan Pourfar), who is manipulating her niece for her personal gain.
Ashley O's story is told in parallel with that of estranged sisters Rachel (excellently portrayed by Angourie Rice) and Jack (winningly played by Madison Davenport). Rachel and Jack are raised by their apathetic, workaholic father since the death of their mother 2 years prior and both are distant and unconfident. Rachel is shy and friendless and compensates by obsessively following Ashley O's career, while Jack is sarcastic and bitter and hides away creating depressing music. On Rachel's birthday, her Dad buys her an Ashley Too doll and this affects the 2 girls' lives in important ways.The acting in this is uniformly excellent. Cyrus is compelling in the dramatic scenes and hilarious as the doll voice. This quirky episode was the perfect vehicle for her. Rice and Davenport are very believable as sisters and their scenes with Ashley Too are simultaneously sweet, charming, and hilarious. Parfour is a perfect foil, subtly malicious without overdoing it. As much as I generally disliked Season 4, the two best episodes were easily USS Callister and Hang the DJ, both of which had a ton of humor interspersed with the drama. You can add Rachel Jack and Ashley Too to the list of successful darkly humorous episodes in the Black Mirror universe. To hell with the ridiculously low rating. This episode was a winner!

Title: Cheesy teen comedy action drama
Comment:
Wow, that went down hill fast. A kind of an interesting set up devolved into rock industry cliches and silly car chases for no reason. Well beneath Charlie Brooker's usual standard. Would he really have written it to play out like this?
There's some decent social observation in the first 20 mins. with the empty rhetoric "you can do it" falling flat etc, but maybe it's the execution of the material that ruined it? Blame the director.
I don't know what else to say. Pulling this one out just doesn't make sense for the series. why would you deliver this to people who you know want more intellect in their entertainment. Misjudged on so many levels.

Title: im only giving it 4 because i love miley syrus
Comment: Okay. Im done with this season. black mirror so far was for me the best of netflix shows and now they ruin it with this season ? especially with this bad episode that when i watch i thinked of it as disney show or something.

Title: Not great but not bad.
Comment: I get part of the reason why people dislike this episode, it stars Miley Cyrus as a tween pop star singing manufactured bubblegum rock songs of empowerment. But like a lot of the episodes this season you really need to look beyond the curtain to get what they're getting at.We have Miley Cyrus playing Ashley, the biggest tween pop star out there and she's come out with a new product Ashley II. Imagine Alexa combined with Eve from the movie Wall-E but with Ashley's personality built in. Yes, it's an actual AI patterned on Ashley herself. It's the perfect gift for all her fans. You can talk to it and will respond as Ashley would. What fan wouldn't want such an upbeat and encouraging friend?But like all these episodes there's a much darker side to it. Ashley herself is as much a product as this little robot friend you can buy. She's controlled by her agent and her handlers to only pump out these commercially popular happy, feel good songs when she wants to write the music she wants to write. But she's forced to keep it up due to her contract.Well guess what? That little Ashley II is also constrained by her programming. It's not just an AI that is patterned after Ashley, it's her actual personality in there but limited to only being happy, chirpy and encouraging. You know, exactly like what the real Ashley is being forced to be.Since Ashley no longer wants to play ball her manager conspires to fake a little accident putting Ashley in to a coma which she will, supposedly, never wake up from. One of these Ashley II robots sees this, has an existential moment, and due to some fiddling with her programming the whole personality of Ashley is now available to her. Remember the episode "White Christmas" with Jon Hamm? They had come up with a way to copy your entire personality into a chip and place it in a small device that you could use, like Alexa, that could be used to run your daily schedule and your home. It's a callback to that episode. And it's made even more horrifying once you realize how Ashley II has been recalled due to it being defective and we them being destroyed. Each one of those contains the real Ashley's personality and consciousness. They're killing her over and over again or, to put it into more common terms, she's being chewed up by the music industry. It's another metaphor guys.But two sisters, along with the now conscious Ashley II, make their way to Ashley's home and rescue her. The plans of her manager are revealed to the world and Ashley is now performing the music she wants.Not the worst episode I've ever seen and honestly while I'm not a fan of Miley Cyrus I have to admit she can act for the most part and does a decent cover or "Head Like a Hole" by Nine Inch Nails.

Title: 5x03
Comment: Mmmm yeah not really a fan of that one. It's a shame because it seems like a really good idea that's just been squandered. I tried to like it and for a while I think I did genuinely like it, and I know this show takes its fair share of creative liberties and for the most part they're really really small things, but this episode just took the cake. It got to the point where it was a bit too ridiculous and a bit too melodramatic and a bit too much. I can definitely see it and it does make sense but it's just a no from me. There certainly could've been a way to use this idea for a government conspiracy or something along those lines that would've been so much better than what we got. This was just an episode about music industry corruption, which I didn't mind but it was a bit too clich√© and like I said before I really think there was so much more that could've been done with an idea like that. The leads were annoying at best and while it was a fun episode, I do hope it's the last one they do. Or if they do more, make them like USS Callister instead because this one wasn't itHigh 6

Title: Got a feeling someone's having a dig at their former employers
Comment:

Title: How to describe...
Comment: Wow, Rachel, Jack & Ashley Too was atrocious! Utter garbage & shockingly crap episode of Black Mirror - easily the worst in the show's history. Felt like a cheesy movie made by Disney Channel. Quite astounding to think it was written by Charlie Brooker - the same man responsible for creating stories like "Hated in The Nation" & "The Entire History of You". To try & do its inadequacy justice, I can only say it's exactly the type of "Americanised" episode we all feared Black Mirror would become once it was announced Netflix was to take over the series' production; the nuanced, subtle messages are non-existent & we're left with a reductive alternative which lacks even a shred of relevance when compared to any predecessor installment. What happened to the bleak, foreboding & witty original we all fell in love with? The sharp critique of society & our flawed behaviours? This - on the other hand - is stupid. Irredeemably nonsensical & ridiculous. Clich√©d, hammy & cringey. There's bad & then there's BAD & THIS bad is indefensible.

Comment: So, suspension of disbelief is a thing we allow ourselves to invest in for out own enjoyment.But this actually made me laugh when the plot twist kicked in, I actually "LOLd". It was just a silly idea and execution.It's entertaining, just not very credible.

Title: Pop Divas of the Future
Comment: The final episode of season five takes us into the world of the pop music industry in the future. The main characters are on the title: Ashley (Miley Cyrus) is a pop singer, Rachel is the shy new girl in school and a big fan of Ashley, and Jack is Rachel's goth sister.The final episode has a less serious tone. It's lighter, has hilarious moments, and the plot is also twisted but predictable. The acting is pretty good. Not a fan of how it ended though. I wish the story became a little bit more inventive.

Title: Brooker checks out on a low point
Comment: This entire episode seems like a giant fanwank over Miley Cyrus, who, granted, does a decent job playing all aspects of her character. But that's not enough to carry the episode.Angourie Rice is nubile and legal, and also turns in a decent ing√©nue performance. Susan Pourfar is solid too, but Madison Davenport is far too old for her role, and her part and performance are unappealing.Thus far, thus fair, but the plot is twist-free, provokes no thoughts, and doesn't feel like a Black Mirror episode at all. It's a novelty, and it's clear that most of the budget was spunked on Cyrus with little left over for sets or extras.It's a very curious way to end the series and likely the entire show, and a bitter pill to swallow after the tastier fare that preceded it.
